content: Merger-and-acquisition activity in the U.S. has been robust so far this year — the most in value since 2007 — thanks to a couple of huge deals in the works, including Charter Communications' $78.4 billion bid for Time Warner Cable and other transactions in media, technology and health care. From Jan. 1 to May 29, M&A activity reached $750.2 billion…

Charter Communications (CHTR) is close to a deal to buy larger Time Warner Cable (TWC) for $195 a share, according to multiple reports, after the Comcast (CMCSA)-TWC takeover failed due to regulatory opposition.Charter, the No. 3 U.S. cable operator, will pay $100 a share in cash and the rest in stock, for each share of No. 2 TWC, Bloomberg reported on Monday, citing sources. The Financial Times and Reuters later filed similar reports.Both Bloomberg and FT said Charter would also buy Bright House, a smaller cable operator. Charter had a deal for Bright House earlier this year, but that agreement hinged on No. 1 Comcast buying Time Warner Cable.Time Warner Cable stock rose 3.4% to 171.18 on Friday, hitting a record 172.21 intraday. The stock rose 9.4% for the week amid growing speculation that Charter on French telecom Altice would make an offer.Charter closed Friday down 1.9% to 175.33, the lowest close in three months. Charter had sought to buy TWC last year, but was thwarted by Comcast.Charter's top shareholder is John Malone's Liberty Broadband (LBRDA).Separately, Cablevision (CVC) shares leapt 22.3% last week to their highest levels in nearly four years. But it's unclear if Cablevision is really a buyout target.Follow Ed Carson on Twitter: @IBD_ECarson.
Best Mutual Funds 2015: May Performance Report
Corporate takeovers were the theme for May, boosting mutual funds holding these stocks and testifying to resilience in the U.S. economy, even as mixed economic data trickled in.

The parade of pairings includedCharter (CHTR) and Time Warner (TWC), Avago (AVGO) and Broadcom (BRCM), Ascena (ASNA) and Ann (ANN), CVS (CVS) and Omnicare (OCR), Verizon (VZ) and AOL (AOL), and Danaher (DHR) and Pall (PLL).

"M&A activity continues to support the U.S. stock market," Russ Koesterich, BlackRock's global chief investment strategist, wrote May 26. The deals allow companies to expand into new markets, as well as gain efficiencies and earnings leverage.

And they came despite — or perhaps because of — sluggish manufacturing activity in May and an economy that shrank in the first quarter. In fact, weak data paradoxically boosted stocks because it "alleviated concerns over an aggressive Federal Reserve rate-hiking regime," Koesterich added.
U.S. diversified equity funds rose 1.3% on average in May, according to Lipper Inc. General domestic taxable bond funds fell 0.42%.

Growth funds across the market-cap spectrum continued to notch the biggest gains. Small-cap growth funds beat last month, advancing 2.8% on average. That took their year-to-date gains to 6.2%. Midcap growth funds rallied 2% and 6.8% in the same periods.
Value funds are catching up, posting tidy gains in May but lagging year to date.
Sector-focused mutual funds holding health and biotech stocks proved stellar again. They trumped every other domestic fund category, soaring 7.5% in May and 16.2% in 2015 as of month-end.
Strong Health Care Earnings

Health care companies showed strong first-quarter earnings growth — 21.4% overall, topping all 10 S&P sectors. Stocks such as IBD Sector Leaders Actavis (ACT) and Illumina (ILMN) are profiting from robust demand for innovative drugs and testing equipment, as well as acquisitions of smaller companies to streamline or diversify operations.

As interest rates stay lower for longer, mutual fund investors are seeking out income-producing equities. Utility and telecom funds eked out 0.2% and 0.5% gains last month. Year to date, they're laggards.

Koesterich advises income investors to focus on dividend growth funds. "Many sectors offering high yields, such as utilities, are expensive and the most vulnerable to a rise in rates," he said. "Instead, yield-hungry investors should look for technology, financials, health care and select energy companies offering rising dividends."

The price of gold ended May roughly 1% higher at 1191.40. But a stronger dollar weighed upon bullion as the month wore on. Mutual funds investing in precious metal commodities managed to turn in a 1% gain on average over the course of last month. Virtually every other commodity fund — from ag-based to energy-focused — saw losses.
Precious metal equities funds — such as those holding mining stocks — gave up 1.6% in May. They're more influenced by operational conditions, not just the underlying metal's price.
Modest Gains Abroad
In a reversal from the previous month, investors who turned to foreign markets for successful investing pegged slight declines.

Still, several international regions managed to beat the "sell in May" naysayers, including rallying India, Japan and Europe. But China stock mutual funds fell 0.2% vs. their 14.2% outsize gains in April.
Year to date, China region funds still lead their international peers with a 21.6% surge. But they were hurt in May by stock market news of shrinking factory activity and weak export growth.
Overall, world equity funds dropped 0.5% in May vs. their 4.3% gain the previous month.

"International markets have done pretty well year to date," said Matthew Dobbs, head of global small companies at Schroder Investment Management, "so it's not entirely surprising to see a bit of a reversion back."
Dobbs manages part of the $2.8 billion Vanguard International Explorer Fund , which rose 0.9% in May and is up 12% in 2015. It invests 23.3% of assets in Japan, its biggest single-country allocation.
Japanese mutual funds rose 1.7% in May. They're up 16.5% this year.
Large caps in Japan powered that performance, said Dobbs. The falling yen gave these companies, which tend to have sizable exposure to foreign earnings, a boost.
VINEX also assigns 58.4% of assets to continental Europe and the U.K. European funds rallied 0.5% last month. Year to date, they're up 9.5%. Massive stimulus measures have kick-started markets there.

"Things are getting a little bit better than people expected" at the start of the year, Dobbs said. French telecom Altice's sudden push into the U.S. sets up a potential battle with Charter Communications for Time Warner Cable, as both Altice and Charter eye deals to gain scale so they can bulk up for further takeovers. Altice on Wednesday announced it would buy a 70% stake in Suddenlink Communications, the seventh-biggest U.S. cable TV firm, for about $7.9…
The flirtation between wireless carrier T-Mobile US (TMUS) and satellite TV broadcaster Dish Network (DISH) has reportedly blossomed into merger talks, sending both stocks rising.
The merger would create a stronger competitor to AT&T (T), Verizon Communications (VZ) and Sprint (S).
T-Mobile CEO John Legere would lead the combined company, the Wall Street Journal said. Dish Network CEO Charlie Ergen would be chairman. Germany's Deutsche Telekom (DTEGY) controls T-Mobile.

"Deutsche Telekom holds the keys to T-Mobile and there are no guarantees that minority DT shareholders will be happy with the price in what is likely to be a mostly-stock deal with a 12- to 15-month regulatory review, with some spectrum divestitures required," said Kevin Smithen, an analyst at Macquarie Capital, in a research note.
Ergen and T-Mobile executives have exchanged favorable comments about each other in recent months.
The merger would give T-Mobile wireless spectrum it needs in major U.S. markets, while Dish Network would be able to offer an Internet-based TV service to mobile phone users.
Verizon is expected to soon launch an over-the-top (OTT) mobile video service.
Lots Of Deals Pending

Telecom M&A speculation continues, with Citigroup on Wednesday saying France-based Altice could buy Verizon's local, residential wireline business, including its FiOS TV and Internet business. Altice recently acquired a 70% stake in U.S. No. 7 cable firm Suddenlink Communications for $7.9 billion.
And in late May, Charter Communications (CHTR) agreed to buy Time Warner Cable (TWC) in a $56 billion deal.
Federal regulators would likely approve a Dish Network merger with T-Mobile, analysts say. The Federal Communications Commission in 2014 signaled its opposition to a Sprint merger with T-Mobile.
Comcast (CMCSA) terminated its proposed merger with Time Warner Cable in April amid reports that the FCC and Department of Justice might block that deal.
AT&T's proposed merger with satellite TV broadcaster DirecTV Group (DTV) is expected to get a green light this month or next.
Verizon has said it's not interested in acquiring Dish Network outright, though some analysts have speculated that Verizon and Dish will form a partnership involving radio spectrum.
The public flirtation between T-Mobile and Dish Network has fueled merger speculation. Dish Network has cobbled together an average of 80 MHz in major U.S. markets, more than T-Mobile.
Ergen on Dish's Q1 earnings call said T-Mobile remains a potential partner.
"We're keeping all our options open, and we admire what (CEO John Legere) and his team have done with T-Mobile," Ergen said at the time.
T-Mobile's aggressive Uncarrier promotions, which started with installment payment plans for mobile phones, spurred subscriber growth in 2013 and 2014.
At a financial conference in late February, Legere said: "Dish and we, that makes some sense." T-Mobile CFO Braxton Carter echoed Legere's remark a week later.

Dish Network stock was up 6% in morning trading in the stock market today, near 75. T-Mobile stock was up nearly 5%, at a more than seven-year high above 40. Verizon stock was down nearly 2% in morning trading Thursday.
Mike McCormack, analyst at Jefferies, says much remains uncertain about the talks.

"The deal structure remains in question. A partnership scenario is also possible," said McCormack in a report. Time Warner Cable (TWC) posted Q1 earnings early Thursday that missed views though it added 30,000 video subscribers, as Morgan Stanley speculated that Charter Communications could pay up to $185 per share to acquire TWC. No. 2 cable firm TWC's proposed takeover by No. 1 Comcast (CMCSA) was called off last week on opposition from the Department of Justice antitrust…

Charter Communications (CHTR) reportedly is exploring a bid for Time Warner Cable (TWC) after Comcast (CMCSA) scrapped its $45 billion takeover deal for Time Warner Cable.Charter soon may approach the No. 2 U.S. cable provider with a bid, the Wall Street Journal said, albeit one that is a better offer than it received from Comcast because Time Warner's stock price and operations have improved. Charter will send advisers to contact TWC about talks, Bloomberg said.Charter shares rose 1.2% on the stock market today. Comcast edged up 0.7%, and Time Warner Cable climbed 4.4%.Charter is unlikely to attempt a hostile takeover like it did in January 2014, sources told the Journal. Time Warner Cable rejected Charter's offer before accepting the one made by Comcast early last year.That megadeal was sunk after U.S. regulators — as well as consumer advocates — raised concerns about its potential effect on competition and consumers, including higher broadband prices.Time Warner Cable reportedly is concerned about the debt levels involved in a possible merger with Charter, since Charter would have to raise a lot of money. Time Warner also considers Charter's shares to be overvalued, the Journal said.Charter recently announced a $10.4 billion deal to buy Bright House cable assets — but that was contingent on the Comcast-TWC deal.

If Comcast's deal to buy Time Warner Cable collapses from a regulatory steamroller, observers say both companies may resurface in telecom takeovers. Both the Justice Department, which reviews mergers on antitrust grounds, and the Federal Communications Commission, which examines whether deals are in the public interest, have signaled that Comcast-TWC could be shot down. The merger would combine the nation's…

Altice on Wednesday agreed to buy Suddenlink Communications, the seventh largest U.S. cable TV company, amid speculation it's also aiming to acquire No. 2 Time Warner Cable (TWC). Altice's purchase of a 70% stake in Suddenlink marks the second time a French telecom company has targeted the U.S. in less than a year. French upstart Iliad in October dropped its…

Comcast (CMCSA) pulled the plug on its proposed acquisition of Time Warner Cable as analysts said the Obama administration's opposition to the deal is a harbinger of tougher regulation for cable TV and broadband service companies. Both the Justice Department and the Federal Communications Commission had signaled that the Comcast-TWC deal would be opposed. Many analysts expect major telecom M&A…

An Apple (AAPL) TV service will likely feature dynamic ad insertion technology based on viewing data that provides upside for media and entertainment companies that partner with Apple, speculates Pacific Crest Securities in a research report.

Satellite TV broadcaster Dish Network (DISH) and Sony (SNE) this year launched new OTT (over-the-top) Internet video services. The services are dubbed OTT products because they piggyback landline broadband services sold by other companies.
Apple has been widely expected to join them this year or next. Pacific Crest says this year.
Companies are racing to acquire ad technology as consumer viewing habits shift to mobile and on-demand platforms.

Verizon Communications (VZ) agreed to buy AOL (AOL) on Tuesday for $4.4 billion. The acquisition will give Verizon key advertising technology as well as content to offer on its mobile video platform, analysts said.

Pacific Crest analyst Andy Hargreaves does not expect Apple to sell new consumer hardware as part of the TV service launch. Nor does Hargreaves expect a significant EPS lift for Apple from a TV service, at least not in the near term.
Hargreaves says media firms that would get a boost from Apple paying higher programming fees include Time Warner Cable (TWC), Walt Disney (DIS), CBS (CBS) and 21st Century Fox (FOXA).
He called an Apple TV service "disruptive" to the pay-TV ecosystems of Comcast (CMCSA), Charter Communications (CHTR) and other cable TV firms.

"We expect Apple to provide detailed viewing data directly to (cable) network owners ... in addition to collecting data, Apple's service should be able to provide dynamic ad inventory in content that is live, served on-demand, or recorded by the consumer," he wrote. "At the moment, network owners do not get paid for advertising that is recorded and watched outside of the Nielsen-rated three- or seven-day windows. An Apple service should be able to serve ads based on the viewer, content and time of viewing regardless of whether the viewing is done live.

"We expect the service to be a medium-sized bundle of traditional linear networks with significant stacking rights and a heavy emphasis on on-demand viewing, likely with a base price around $40 or $50 per month. We believe Apple will market based on a superior consumer experience, which, if executed well, is likely to be much more disruptive than a 'skinny bundle' (with fewer channels)."

The rise of over-the-top (OTT) Web TV services might drive video subscriber losses at cable TV companies, but cable firms will continue to grab the lion's share of broadband customers as the industry's profit center shifts, say upbeat reports. Internet video services target young adults and other consumers that "cut the cord," those people who disconnect from pay-TV service in…

Charter Communications (CHTR) is reportedly nearing a deal to acquire Bright House Networks, while Comcast says its CFO will leave to head an investment startup. Both developments come ahead of Comcast's  (CMCSA) bid for regulatory approval of its acquisition of Time Warner Cable (TWC), which would unite the two largest cable TV companies. Charter stock gapped up 6.5% in…
Stock futures scraped lower ahead of Tuesday's open, bumped out of early gains by international conflict and a global travel alert. Dow futures dug in 105.7 points and were falling.
Nasdaq 100 futures were 30.7 points below fair market value. S&P 500 futures carved a 12.9-point loss.

Turkey reported that one of its F-16 fighter jets had shot down a Russian aircraft after the plane had been warned it was violating Turkish air space. Russia's defense ministry claimed its aircraft had not strayed into Turkish air space, was flying at 6,000 meters and was shot down from the ground.

In either case, U.S. stock futures veered lower when the news broke. The stock market today felt additional premarket pressure after the U.S. State Department issued a global travel alert for Americans, based on planned terrorist threats across multiple regions, ahead of the travel-heavy Thanksgiving weekend. The alert, a less serious caution than a department travel warning, did not say citizens should not travel. But it advised travelers to remain vigilant and "avoid large crowds or crowded places." The alert expires on Feb. 24.

Airline stocks and travel-related issues such as Priceline.com (PCLN) and TripAdvisor (TRIP) came under moderate premarket pressure following the release. Oil prices rose 1% to 2%, with West Texas Intermediate bobbing back above $42 a barrel and Europe's Brent crude benchmark above $45.

The Commerce Department revised its estimate of third-quarter GDP growth upward to 2.1%. The number was better than the initial estimate of 1.5% growth and in line with economist consensus expectations. The department revised its GDP deflator — a measure of prices — up a notch to a 1.3% gain vs. a first estimate of 1.2%. Consensus projections had held to the 1.2% mark.

Case-Shiller is scheduled to release its 20-City Home Price Index for September at 9 a.m. ET. At 10 a.m., the Conference Board reports its November Consumer Confidence index and the Richmond Federal Reserve puts out its regional manufacturing survey for the month.
All but one of the 30 Dow stocks traded down ahead of the open. Pfizer (PFE) was the holdout, with a 0.3% gain.
Quarterly reports continued to stir heavy early action. Auto salvage consolidator Copart (CPRT) and China-based continuing education specialist Tarena International (TEDU) leapt 5% each.

It was a tough morning for jewelers, with Signet Jewelers (SIG) diving 8% and Tiffany (TIF) down 3%. Both chains missed analyst consensus sales and earnings expectations for their third quarters. Premarket gains and losses often do not carry over into the regular session, but if Signet's loss holds, the stock would open with a gap-down loss and below its 200-day moving average.

IBD 50 stock Dycom (DY) spun a 5% gain after reporting late Monday its fiscal Q1 earnings soared past consensus views, up 110%, while a 29% revenue gain easily topped expectations. Gross margins expanded to 16% from 13% a year ago, and management's Q2 revenue guidance was better than forecasts. The telecom engineering and construction service firm ended Monday still in buy range, 3% above an 80.95 buy point.

Palo Alto Networks (PANW) tacked on a 3% gain. The network security gear maker reported a broad fiscal Q1 beat late Monday. The stock advanced through the past six sessions and is back above its 10-week moving average as it climbs the right side of a two-month consolidation.Stock futures scraped lower ahead of Tuesday's open, bumped out of early gains by international conflict and a global travel alert. Stocks got off to a weak start Tuesday, despite some positive company news and consumer confidence numbers.
The Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq shed 0.5% each. The S&P 500 dipped 0.4%.
Volume was soft, down 18% on the Nasdaq and just 1% lower on the NYSE, compared to trade at the same time Monday.

The stock market today received a bit of a boost from the real estate market, as Case-Shiller's 20-City Composite Home Price Index ticked up 4.6% in January. That was slightly better than the downwardly revised 4.4% gain in December and in line with consensus expectations.

Midwest manufacturing contracted for a second month in March, with Kingsbury International reporting its Chicago Purchasing Managers' Index at 46.3, up from 45.8 in February but below forecasts for an increase to 50.2. Numbers below 50 indicate economic contraction.

Consumer confidence was more positive, with the Conference Board's Consumer Confidence Index jumping to 101.3 for March. That was a big step above February's 96.4 and the reverse of economist expectations, which saw a decline to 95.5. A statement from the Conference Board said the "increase was driven by an improved short-term outlook for both employment and income prospects; consumers were less upbeat about business conditions."

In stocks, CBRE Group (CBG) jumped 7% to a new high. The Los Angeles-based property management firm said it would pay $1.48 billion to acquire the global workspace solutions business from Johnson Controls International (JCI). The unit provides on-site staff for managing and maintaining commercial buildings. The gain put CBRE shares 9% above a 35.47 buy point in a flat base. Johnson Controls rose 2%, to almost 3% above a 49.36 buy point in a double-bottom base.

Six of the Dow's 30 stocks dragged more than 1% in early action. Charter Communications (CHTR) punched to the top of the Nasdaq 100, up 7% after announcing it would buy privately held Bright House, the sixth-largest U.S. cable operator.

The IBD 50 list opened almost unanimously lower, but losses were mild. Noah Holdings (NOAH), Avago Technologies (AVGO) and Gentherm (THRM) staked out the low point on the list, down a little more than 1% each.

Under Armour (UA) posted the strongest early gain among IBD 50 stocks, up 1%. Remote-control maker Universal Electronics (UEIC) fell under the sofa cushions Friday after forecasting first-quarter earnings below what Wall Street was targeting.
Shares of the Santa Ana, Calif.-based company fell 10% Friday to a three-month low above 57. Universal Electronics stock hit an all-time high of 66.75 on Tuesday.

Universal Electronics, aka UEI, reported Q4 results late Thursday. UEI earned 70 cents a share excluding items, up 43% year over year, on sales of $138 million, up 2%. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected 65 cents and $139 million.

For the March quarter, UEI expects to earn 41 to 51 cents a share on sales of $133 million to $141 million. At the midpoint of guidance, EPS would be up 15% and sales up 6%. Wall Street was targeting EPS of 56 cents. Revenue guidance was in line with estimates.

"The company continues to expect the long-term financial profile of its business will reflect average annual sales growth of approximately 5% to 10%, and average annual earnings growth of approximately 10% to 20%," the company said in a press release.
UEI is a leader in wireless control technology for the connected home. It develops technology that enables consumers to control entertainment devices, digital media and home systems.
"Our innovative products and technologies continue to be adopted by industry-leading companies around the world," UEI Chief Executive Paul Arling said in a statement.
In the pay-TV market, its customers include Comcast (CMCSA), DirecTV (DTV), Cox Communications, Charter Communications (CHTR), Cablevision (CVC) and AT&T (T).
UEI also makes embedded software for smart devices such as TVs, set-top boxes, game consoles, smartphones and tablets.

"We believe growth will be driven by embedded software implementations and expanding 'smart' device integration," Piper Jaffray analyst Michael Olson said in a research note Friday. "However, near-term revenue visibility on UEI's continued trajectory into smart devices (phones and televisions, among other devices) is low. We have a positive stance on UEI's long-term growth story."
Olson reiterated his overweight rating on UEI stock, and he raised his price target to 70 from 59.
Dougherty analyst Steven Frankel called UEI's Q4 "a mixed bag."

"The fourth-quarter report wasn't as strong as we expected but doesn't derail our thesis that the shift from embedding its IP (intellectual property) with molded plastic remote controls to selling software/embedded solutions along with traditional remotes sets the stage for material margin expansion and an acceleration in earnings growth," Frankel said in a note Friday.

JPMorgan says a Verizon Communications (VZ) merger with Comcast (CMCSA) is not going to happen, while a deal combining Verizon and No. 2 cable firm Charter Communications (CHTR) looks unlikely, too.But telecom firms Sprint (S) and T-Mobile US (TMUS) are more likely to be in play, says the investment bank."We believe a combination of Verizon and Charter is feasible but difficult on the financials, but Comcast's overall size and NBC ownership make a deal with Verizon a nonstarter as the regulatory review process would likely be quite difficult," JPMorgan analyst Philip Cusick wrote Monday in a broad research report on telecom industry M&A scenarios.Comcast, Charter and other cable TV firms hold rights to lease access to Verizon's mobile network on a wholesale basis, under what's called an MVNO (mobile virtual network operator) agreement. Comcast plans to start wireless-services trials in mid-2017.Cusick says the cable TV firms and Verizon might try to forge a deeper partnership if an outright merger isn't doable, but he says that relationship likely would fray.IBD'S TAKE: Steel maker Nucor, Burlington Stores and Broadcom are on IBD's Leaderboard, which follows top stocks from their work on forming bases, through their breakouts, to their post-breakout action, up to the point where they start topping."We don't believe that an MVNO structure will allow cable to be successful in wireless over time," he said. "Cable's wireless business would eventually grow to a point where Verizon views them as a threat."Shares of Verizon and Comcast fell a fraction in the stock market today, while Charter was flat. But Sprint stock rose 2.8% and T-Mobile 1%. Comcast and Charter are both extended from November breakouts.JPMorgan assigns the highest probability (35%) to Sprint (S) and T-Mobile US (TMUS) proposing a merger, while it estimates a 15% chance that Comcast could bid for T-Mobile or Sprint.Verizon CEO Lowell McAdam recently commented on the "industrial logic" of a Verizon-cable industry tie-up. And in his 2017 industry predictions, T-Mobile CEO John Legere said a Verizon-Comcast merger could happen.JPMorgan, though, says Comcast likely has other ideas, especially if a Sprint merger with T-Mobile does not materialize. Deutsche Telekom (DTEGY), which owns 65% of T-Mobile, could roll its equity into a larger company, says JPMorgan.A Comcast purchase of T-Mobile would be bad news for AT&T (T) and Verizon, says Cusick, because it would "cement" an industry structure with four national players, rather than three. "If the Sprint deal does not work out, a cable transaction becomes the next most likely event for T-Mobile," said Cusick in his report. "We believe that Comcast is very serious about getting into wireless, and we see synergies as substantial."RELATED:Dish Upgraded, Stock Rises On Verizon Takeout ScenariosT-Mobile Hits All-Time High; Comcast, Verizon UpgradedCash Key In SoftBank-Sprint 'Knockout' Offer For T-Mobile?Would T-Mobile Spurn Debt-Laden Sprint For Comcast Offer?Verizon M&A Talk Swirls; Charter Stock Up, Yahoo Down

Stock funds seemed only slightly less frenetic than President Trump setting policy in his first 100 days, as the average domestic stock fund rose 1.83% in January, padding gains of 1.46% in December and 10.81% in 2016.World equity funds did even better in January, advancing 3.86%, according to Lipper Inc.Taxable bond funds rose 0.76%, while municipal bond funds rose 0.46%.The S&P 500 rose 1.90% last month.Not all of the young year's gains are attributable to the new president and new Congress, say stock fund managers and strategists."Regardless of who was elected, the economy was already improving," said Kimberly Scott, lead manager of $2.4 billion Ivy Mid Cap Growth (WMGAX) and co-manager of $288 million Ivy Mid Cap Income Opportunities (IVOAX) funds. "The trajectory of corporate profits had already turned up. The outlook for corporate profits for the end of 2017 into 2018 was already quite strong. The policy changes concerning taxes, repatriation of overseas corporate cash (and) unwinding some onerous regulations that President Trump talked about could boost corporate profits more. But the economy was already getting stronger."And mutual fund professionals expect the uptrend to continue this year."The market could go in two very different ways," said Omar Aguilar, Charles Schwab Investment Management's chief investment officer of equities. "On the one hand, there is a very powerful combination of factors that could translate into record levels for equities."On the other hand, the market could go south. "The attempt at reforms (of taxes, corporate cash repatriation and regulatory burdens) could increase the federal budget deficit," Aguilar said. "There is a potential for trade wars. Emerging markets are still landing. A strong U.S. currency could hurt exports. Those headwinds could backfire into our economy and markets."On balance, Aguilar is guardedly bullish. "On a net basis we will see the market trend up," he said. "But it will be volatile."Scott is favoring stocks in sectors that typically benefit at the outset of a rally. "Many think we're in the midcycle of a recovery," she said. "But we had a significant corporate-profits recession. So to me this feels like an early-stage economic recovery, and that's when you want to shift more asset weight into technology, financials, energy and industry."Consumer discretionary is usually part of that early-stage recovery party. But this time brick-and-mortar retailers are battling digital retailers. Brick-and-mortar retailers are being forced to spend on their own websites and low-cost delivery services, Scott says, which will continue to sap their earnings.Large-cap growth mutual funds' 4.10% gain on average in January led all U.S. diversified stock fund categories.Yet investors were still jittery enough at times to drive precious-metals funds, a defensive category, up 14.94% last month, higher than any other sector. That beat basic-materials funds, which gained 7.31%.Latin American funds paced foreign stock fund categories by tacking on 7.67%.Taxable bonds were led by flexible-income funds 1.61% gain. Treasury funds inched up 0.36%.Trailing precious metals and several other sector fund categories, tech funds notched a 5.13% January gain. IPG Photonics (IPGP) is a technology name that John Barr, manager of $60 million Needham Aggressive Growth (NEAGX) — whose 9.32% average annual gain over the past 10 years topped 96% of its small-cap growth rivals tracked by Morningstar Inc. — likes in a market poised to continue higher but with volatility. The company makes fiber-optic lasers, which can be used for cutting and welding in industrial applications. As costs fall, laser systems become increasingly attractive, especially in welding, Barr says. "Big automotive makers are quite interested in using this for welding," he said.Revenue grew 19% and 17% in the two most recent years. Earnings grew an average of 18% annually from 2014 to 2016. "It has a long runway ahead, with great returns and great management," Barr said.PDF Solutions (PDFS) is another tech name Barr likes. The firm produces software that's the core of electrical testing of newly made semiconductors. It has the potential for taking share from more conventional optical testing systems, Barr says.Two major chipmakers signed on as customers in 2016. PDF's service is delivered on a subscription basis. "So it has high margins and could double company earnings" in the near term, Barr said, especially if it wins customers in China as the Middle Kingdom builds out its own semiconductor manufacturing industry between now and 2020.Ivy's Scott likes MercadoLibre (MELI), an Argentina-based online retailer that offers an electronic payment service. "It's still in an earlier phase of development than Amazon (AMZN) is here," said Scott. "There is no reason to think that demand for online buying and payment will not be as attractive to Latin Americans as it is in the U.S. and Asia."Video-game publisher Electronic Arts (EA) is another of Scott's favorites. The video-game publisher benefits from a console-upgrade cycle and the shift to digital game downloads, which carry higher profit margins, as IBD has reported. Scott says now, "I continue to like the tremendous changes in the products and innovation there. They make games that consumers love. And the way that these products are developed and distributed digitally is such a profit enhancer. We think that story continues."Among financial services stocks, Scott likes regional banks such as First Republic (FRC) and Signature Bank (SBNY), which should benefit from rising rates and from a reduction in their regulatory burden. Trump targeted the Dodd-Frank Act for review on Friday.IBD'S TAKE: Midsize regional banks have gotten a boost from congressional moves to raise the threshold of the Dodd-Frank Act's systemic risk designation. The existing rule applies to banks with at least $50 billion in assets, subjecting them to costly regulations. As IBD recently reported, Congress is looking at raising that to $250 billion.Scott also likes MarketAxess Holdings (MKTX), an electronic bond-trading exchange that claims cheaper transaction costs than traditional investment-bank bond trades, easier odd-lot trading and specialization in corporate credit. "There are others trying to do this, but none has gained the traction that MarketAxess has," she said.Amid the rally in energy stocks, Stephen DeNichilo, co-manager of $2.9 billion Federated Kaufmann Large Cap (KLCAX), likes small-cap Independence Contract Drilling (ICD). The company offers customers of energy exploration and production very sophisticated drilling rigs. "They're on the leading edge of what E&P companies want," DeNichilo said. "They have only 12 working rigs, so essentially they are fully utilized. They have leverage to the U.S. shale-pad drilling rally. They have a clean balance sheet. They are trading below their $10-a-share replacement value. And they could be a takeout candidate."In addition to trading below 10, earnings per share growth has declined at triple-digit paces the past four quarters.Among industrials, DeNichilo likes Dycom Industries (DY). "We like long-term investment themes," DeNichilo said. "Dycom is the largest specialty contractor for fiber-(optic cable). They're the only national specialty contractor that puts fiber into the ground at a time when AT&T (T), CenturyLink (CTL), Charter (CHTR), Verizon (VZ) and other (telecoms) are about to ramp up."That cycle will be sparked, DeNichilo says, by AT&T embarking on a massive plan to lay fiber so the telecom giant can offer customers high-speed internet service. "Their plan is to bring 1-gigabit speed to (at least) 12 million customers by 2019," DeNichilo said. The industry has seen that when dramatically higher speeds are offered at the same or comparable cost, customers switch providers. "Competitors will have to follow," he said. "This will be a big cycle for Dycom. Also, fiber investments could be part of any large infrastructure (upgrade) plan by the government."At the average U.S. broadband speed of about 18 megabits, downloading a two-hour movie takes more than 10 minutes. It takes eight seconds via 1-Gig fiber, according to fastmetrics.com. And AT&T's speed upgrade can be achieved solely through street-side fiber, and will not require any in-home rewiring or cable replacement, DeNichilo says.Dycom's earnings grew an average of 74% annually over the past three years. "Despite earnings growth way above the market, they are trading below the market multiple," DeNichilo said.DeNichilo also likes Martin Marietta Materials (MLM). As the U.S. economy heats up, demand for construction aggregates will grow. "Even without Trump's Mexican wall, nonresidential construction — which is the bulk of aggregate consumption — is still below its 55-year normal level," he said. "This company has essentially doubled earnings per share over the past three years, so its outlook is fantastic whether there is a (federal government) infrastructure plan or not."Ivy's Scott likes water-heater-maker A.O. Smith (AOS). "There isn't a lot of cyclicality in their business," Scott said. "Homeowners have to replace their heaters every 10 to 12 years. And they have a growing business in China for water heaters and water-purification systems. It's a nice growth engine for Smith."Smith's average annual earnings growth rate was 24% from 2014 through 2016. "They're a consistent grower and reliable payer of dividends," Scott added. The company's dividend yield is 1.1%. "We're not a dividend fund, but it's nice to have on top of everything."RELATED: Where Fund Bigwigs Expect To See Stock Gains In 20172017 Personal Finance Action Plan & 2016 Stock Market ReviewClick Here To See A List Of New Buys Of Top Mutual FundsClick Here To See A List Of Latest Sells Of Top Mutual Funds

The Dow Jones industrial average hit 20,000 as the major averages rallied to fresh record highs on President Trump's early policy moves. Earnings reports generally were positive, but Google parent Alphabet (GOOGL), Starbucks (SBUX) were among those with disappointing results. M&A deals, buzz and rejections were rife.The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 1.3% for the week, topping 20,000 for the first time. The Nasdaq and S&P 500 also hit record highs, up 1.9% and 1%, respectively, amid a slew of earnings, including Intel (INTC), Alphabet (GOOGL), Microsoft (MSFT), Alibaba (BABA) and Boeing (BA). President Trump authorized a border wall and two key oil pipelines, lifting a wide variety of construction and materials related firms such as Caterpillar (CAT) and Martin Marietta Materials (MLM), but not steel makers. Amazon (AMZN) and Facebook (FB) broke out, joining other FANG+ stocks. The 10-year Treasury yield rose, lifting bank stocks.Google parent Alphabet said Q4 earnings per share minus items rose 8% to $9.36, below views for $9.64. Total revenue rose 22% to $26.1 billion, topping forecasts for 25.26 billion. Revenue growth slowed from 28% in the prior-year period. The internet search and advertising giant faced tough comparisons with the prior-year quarter, when it launched new advertising products. Capital spending soared 46% to $3.1 billion, which much of that related to its cloud computing efforts. Marketing costs for Google's new Pixel smartphones also were heavy.Alphabet shares fell 1.4% on Friday after hitting record highs earlier in the week.RELATED:Alphabet Q4 EPS Misses ExpectationsFiscal Q2 earnings rose 9% to 83 cents a share while revenue climbed 2% to $26.07 billion, beating views for 79 cents and $25.30 billion. TV broadcasters reduced their asking price for prime wireless airwaves for the fourth time — to just over $10 billion from what was once $86 billion, though now for a reduced amount of spectrum — setting the stage for a possible auction failure if wireless phone companies and other bidders do not bite at the fire-sale price.The Federal Communications Commission has imposed a quiet period on bidders, banning any strategic talks during the action, which began in March.If the auction ends suddenly, it would open the doors to renewed merger talks among phone companies and cable TV firms. In that case, industry speculation would focus on T-Mobile US (TMUS), Sprint (S), Comcast (CMCSA), Dish Network (DISH) and Verizon Communications (VZ), as well as others.In the meantime, AT&T (T) is seeking approval to buy Time Warner (TWX) for $85 billion, a deal that itself could spark other M&A talks.In earlier auction rounds, TV broadcasters lowered their asking price from $86 billion to $54.6 billion, then to $40.3 billion, and then again to $19.7 billion.The $10 billion-plus reduced price would be for up to 84 MHz of radio spectrum, down from the original plans to auction off 120 MHz of airwaves.TV broadcasters can walk away if bids do not meet the now drastically reduced price tag. While there is an overall goal, the bidding process involves blocks of airwaves in local markets such as New York and Chicago, as well as much smaller markets.IBD'S TAKE: The auction outcome is especially important to T-Mobile, which analysts say needs more airwaves. But T-Mobile could fill its needs through a merger or partnerships as well. T-Mobile stock jumped in late 2016 on speculation that it could merge with Sprint during a Trump administration. Learn more about T-Mobile at IBD Stock CheckupThe auction resumes on Jan. 18. Analysts say it's possible that the two biggest wireless firms, AT&T and Verizon, are no longer aggressively bidding.AT&T appears likely to win the federal contract award for FirstNet, the federal government's plan to create a nationwide wireless broadband network dedicated to public safety, analysts say. As part of the FirstNet contract, AT&T would gain access to a swath of 20 MHz of spectrum.The auction's outcome is important to Dish Network, which has amassed nearly 80 MHz of spectrum but has spent years looking for a wireless partner.While Verizon looms as a partner for Dish, another scenario is that Verizon could deepen its relationship with cable TV firms Comcast and Charter Communications (CHTR) under a wholesale network leasing agreement.Broadcasting and Cable reported that the FCC's soon-to-be Republican majority has been asked by one TV station owner to hit the pause button on the broadcast incentive auction and re-evaluate its "anemic participation" by wireless providers.RELATED:AT&T Seen Winning FirstNet, May Roil TV Airwaves AuctionHow Verizon, Comcast, Dish, T-Mobile Figure In Telecom M&A ScenariosSpectrum Wild Cards May Add Supply, Impact Verizon, T-Mobile, AT&T

Examples abound about how internet, media and telecom companies are accelerating their push into mobile video:Why the rush?As more consumers watch video on mobile phones, the U.S. advertising market hit a milestone in 2016: Digital ad spending surpassed TV ad spending for the first time, projected market tracker eMarketer.Desktop PC display and search ads are still the biggest categories of digital spending. But mobile ad spending has emerged as the main driver of digital revenue, jumping 45% to $46 billion in 2016, forecasts eMarketer.By 2019, mobile ad spending is expected to represent one-third of total media ad spending in the U.S., mainly driven by video ads.Oft-called the third screen after broadcast TV and PCs, mobile ranking must be adjusted, says Roger Entner, founder of Recon Analytics."Mobile is eating the internet," said Entner, coining a phrase similar to venture capitalist Marc Andreessen's "Why Software Is Eating the World" essay five years ago."Seventy percent of mobile traffic is video," Entner added. "The mobile device is turning into the first screen to entertain and inform yourself. It was the third screen, now it's becoming the first screen, overtaking television and the desktop."John Legere, CEO of T-Mobile US (TMUS), has a mantra of his own: "All content is going to the internet, and the internet is going mobile."T-Mobile in 2016 shook up the wireless market with free video streaming for many popular apps.IBD'S TAKE: Netflix's success adding subscribers outside the U.S. is just one reason it makes the IBD Leaderboard, a listing of top stocks poised to possibly bring the biggest gains. See what other companies make the current list.So how does a stock investor play the mobile video trend? Let's imagine a word association game. What companies come to mind first for "mobile video"?Probably not Apple (AAPL) — yet. Probably not Netflix (NFLX), for that matter.Apple's huge base of iPhone users represent a lot of mobile screens, but Apple apparently has shelved plans for its own web TV service, unable to forge a deal with broadcasters. Apple, though, reportedly has lowered the amount it charges to sell video services through its widely used App Store, which should increase the movies and TV shows offered to iPhone users from other parties. Apple reportedly cut its fee to 15% from 30% of monthly subscription billings.Netflix, the top provider of subscription video-on-demand services, doesn't sell advertising. Netflix has invested in long-form, original content rather than shorter video clips. Netflix in early 2016 accounted for only 3.7% of mobile data traffic but 35% of fixed-line broadband traffic, said a report from networking gear maker Sandvine. Its study doesn't measure Wi-Fi network usage, where Netflix traffic might be high.AT&T and Verizon Communications (VZ) make a match for mobile video investing plays. Verizon acquired AOL for $4.4 billion in 2016 and has agreed to buy Yahoo (YHOO). Verizon aims to build a digital ad platform rivaling those of Google and Facebook.And in late 2015, Verizon launched its G090 mobile video service, which targets millennials. The free, ad-supported Go90 service offers a mix of original web TV series, live sports, concert streaming and more. While Go90 has been off to a rocky start (Verizon has not disclosed any operating metrics), the telecom firm has brought in new executives to reboot content and build a bigger audience for ads.AT&T , meanwhile, in late November launched its DirecTV Now video streaming service, which starts at $35 per month. The linchpin to AT&T's mobile video strategy is allowing its wireless subscribers to stream DirecTV Now without eating into their monthly data caps.Entner says AT&T will pressure other new entrants in live TV streaming — such as Hulu, Amazon and Google's YouTube — to develop "mobile-first" strategies. Hulu is a joint venture of 21st Century Fox (FOXA), Walt Disney (DIS), and Comcast.AT&T in late October agreed to buy Time Warner for $85.4 billion. Its assets include HBO, sports-oriented Turner Broadcasting, and a stake in Hulu.The Time Warner deal is designed to "get the most content to the most people at the lowest prices, delivered on any screen, particularly mobile," AT&T CEO Randall Stephenson told analysts.If AT&T's DirecTV Now succeeds, it could pressure Comcast and Charter Communications (CHTR) to acquire a wireless firm, perhaps T-Mobile, some analysts speculate.The conundrum for AT&T and traditional media companies pushing into mobile video is that the younger age groups advertisers covet tend to watch shorter pieces, not long-form content. User-generated and social-media-shared content is still the biggest part of mobile video consumption. And live streaming via Facebook, YouTube and Twitter's (TWTR) Periscope compete for millennial attention against streaming pay-TV services such as CBS (CBS) All Access, which recently disclosed it has 1.2 million subscribers.On Facebook's Q3 earnings call Nov. 2, CEO Mark Zuckerberg trumpeted plans to become a "video-first" company. Zuckerberg says that within five years most of what people consume online will be video. Analysts speculate Facebook could develop a stand-alone app that competes directly with YouTube.Then, there's the Facebook-Instagram rival Snapchat, which has some 400 million users. Snapchat claims that it has some 10 billion daily video views. It limits videos to 10 seconds in length. Snapchat also offers its "Discover" portal of short-clip web videos. Owner Snap has filed for a confidential IPO and is expected to debut on the stock market early in 2017.While Google and Facebook dominate digital advertising, one question is whether another top digital publisher will emerge, such as Snapchat or Verizon, William Blair analyst Bhavan Suri wrote in a recent research report.As for the question near the top of this story: Asked what comes to his mind first when he hears the term "mobile video," Entner quickly replied "YouTube.""Mobile video is still dominated by YouTube," he said. "There is tremendous innovation. People you've never heard of start their own video channel and suddenly have more followers than people who watch episodes of 'The Big Bang Theory.'"RELATED:Alphabet, Facebook Dominate Mobile App Downloads

T-Mobile US (TMUS) added 1.2 million postpaid subscribers in Q4, including 933,000 phone subscribers, topping estimates, while CEO John Legere declared that the "Uncarrier"-branded wireless firm will sell only unlimited data plans starting in late January.T-Mobile's Q4 postpaid subscriber additions will again likely lead the industry, analysts say.T-Mobile preannounced Q4 subscriber additions at the CES show in Las Vegas.T-Mobile ramped up a "free" Apple (AAPL) iPhone 7 (with eligible trade-in) promotion as well as its unlimited data "T-Mobile One" offering in the December quarter.CEO Legere said it will sell only unlimited data plans as of Jan. 22, eliminating data buckets for families and individuals."New rules are needed for the mobile internet. Who wants a rate plan that bills in bits and bytes? It's a relic. Data buckets are over. We're going 100% unlimited with T-Mobile One. It's the only plan we will have."IBD'S TAKE: Verizon and AT&T have been favorites of investors looking for high dividends, but there are other options, such as banks, industrials and real estate investment trusts (REITs). Check out IBD's Income Investor for high-dividend-paying stocks.T-Mobile One unlimited data plans start at $70 for one subscriber; a four-line family plan costs $160 monthly. Taxes and fees will be included under the new T-Mobile One offer, the company said.The company's Uncarrier marketing campaign, launched in March 2013, has enabled T-Mobile to gain subscriber and revenue market share vs. AT&T (T), Verizon Communications (VZ) and Sprint (S). AT&T has been the biggest loser of postpaid phone subscribers.Analysts had estimated that T-Mobile would add 902,000 postpaid phone subscribers in Q4. Postpaid subscribers — those billed monthly — are more lucrative for carriers than prepaid users, who buy minutes as needed.T-Mobile added 1.29 million postpaid subscribers overall in Q4 2015, including tablet users, and 917,000 postpaid phone subscribers. Deutsche Telekom (DTEGY) controls T-Mobile US.T-Mobile stock fell 2.1% to 57.61 in the stock market today, a day after touching a record high of 59.46. T-Mobile stock jumped 47% in 2016, with most of the gain coming in Q4.Observers speculate Sprint and T-Mobile could renew merger talks during a Trump administration. Comcast (CMCSA) could also bid for T-Mobile, perhaps teaming with Charter Communications (CHTR), analysts say.T-Mobile, though, continues to outperform rivals on its own.T-Mobile in October reported higher-than-expected Q3 profit and raised full-year EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization).Jennifer Fritzche, a Wells Fargo analyst, estimates that AT&T lost 220,000 postpaid phone subscribers in Q4, despite unveiling its new DirecTV Now mobile video service in late November. Fritzche estimates Verizon added 57,000 postpaid phone subscribers in the December quarter.While AT&T and Verizon now offer monthly installment payment plans for mobile phones, they have not matched every T-Mobile promotion. T-Mobile has added 4.1 million postpaid subscribers in 2016.Bellevue, Wash.-based T-Mobile in October raised its 2016 postpaid phone subscriber forecast to 3.8 million at the midpoint of its guidance, up from its earlier estimates of 3.4 million and 2.9 million. T-Mobile led the industry with 4.5 million postpaid phone subscriber adds in 2015 and 4.9 million in 2014.RELATED:How Verizon, Comcast, Dish, T-Mobile Figure In Telecom M&A ScenariosVerizon M&A Talk Swirls; Charter Stock Up, Yahoo DownWould T-Mobile Spurn Debt-Laden Sprint For Comcast Offer?

Earnings and revenue growth might play a secondary role for telecom stocks in 2017 amid speculation over a potential burst of mergers and acquisitions, but T-Mobile US (TMUS) and Charter Communications (CHTR) stand out for the possible growth of their bottom lines."2017 is setting up to be potentially one of the most dramatic years in recent memory in terms of reshaping the telecom sector," Simon Flannery, Morgan Stanley's longtime telecom analyst, said in a mid-December research report.T-Mobile, controlled by Germany's Deutsche Telekom (DTEGY), figures in many M&A scenarios, along with Sprint (S), Comcast (CMCSA), Verizon Communications (VZ), Dish Network (DISH) and Charter.AT&T (T), meanwhile, is seeking regulatory approval to buy media giant Time Warner (TWX)."The prospect for a sizable number of announced and potential future M&A deals could significantly benefit some companies, while challenging others in the sector," Flannery wrote.IBD'S TAKE: Verizon and AT&T have been favorites of investors looking for high dividends, but there are other options, such as real estate investment trusts (REITs) and banks. The spotlight shifts to AT&T (T), Verizon Communications (VZ), T-Mobile US (TMUS) and other registered bidders next week in a government spectrum auction, after TV broadcasters again reduced their asking price for prime wireless airwaves, this time to $40.3 billion.In two earlier rounds, TV broadcasters initially sought $86 billion for 100 megahertz of usable radio spectrum, then dropped their asking price to $54.6 billion for 90 MHz. If bidders agree to pay at least $40.3 billion combined, that would open up 80 MHz of airwaves for mobile video and other data services.While there is an overall goal, the bidding process involves blocks of airwaves in local markets, such as New York and Chicago, as well as much smaller ones. The Federal Communications Commission has set price ranges for specific markets.The next stage of the auction might start as soon as Monday. The big question is whether AT&T, Verizon, T-Mobile, Comcast (CMCSA) and other registered bidders will bite at the reduced, $40.3 billion price tag. Broadcasters, meanwhile, could walk away from the auction at any point if disappointed.IBD'S TAKE: A successful auction is important to T-Mobile, which analysts say is most in need of more airwaves. T-Mobile stock is up nearly 40% in 2016. Dish Network stock has been in a trading range since the auction started in March. Learn more about Comcast, another registered bidder, at IBD Stock CheckupIt's not clear if the auction will be affected if FCC Chairman Tom Wheeler resigns in January, when Republican President-elect Donald Trump takes office.The shift to a Republican-led FCC "could leave the spectrum auction inconclusive," said Amy Yong, a Macquarie Capital analyst, in a research report.UBS analyst John Hodulik says the auction will likely move into a fourth round in late December, extending into 2017. He says ultimately only 60 MHz or 70 MHz in total could be auctioned, at a lower price point around $30 billion.The FCC has imposed a quiet period on bidders, banning strategic talks among them until the auction is over."A quicker end to the auction would be positive for T-Mobile and Dish Network (DISH)," said Hodulik in a report. "Once the auction ends, the anti-collusion rules no longer apply, likely paving the way for discussions around strategic initiatives and M&A."Citigroup analyst Michael Rollins also forecasts a spectrum price tag of around $30 billion."Verizon likely did not place a meaningful deposit and is not a meaningful bidder at this auction," said Rollins in a report Friday. "We believe Verizon's actions and continued stated preference for mid-band spectrum supports our view that Verizon is likely to pursue an acquisition of Dish's spectrum or all of Dish at some point in the future."Another scenario, analysts say, is that Verizon could deepen its relationship with cable TV firms Comcast and Charter Communications (CHTR) under a wholesale network leasing agreement.Shares of Dish fell 1.2% to 55.55 while AT&T was off 0.7% to 38.61 on the stock market today. Verizon inched down 6 cents to 49.81 and T-Mobile was up a fraction to 54.44.RELATED:How Verizon, Comcast, Dish, T-Mobile Figure In Telecom M&A ScenariosSpectrum Wild Cards May Add Supply, Impact Verizon, T-Mobile, AT&T

At the urging of Republican lawmakers, FCC Chairman Tom Wheeler late Wednesday removed the "controversial items" from the FCC's Thursday meeting agenda. Republicans wanted to give President-elect Donald Trump time to set up his new administration before the agency vote on such items as a proposal to regulate prices in the $20 billion market for business data services.The move by Republican lawmakers was similar to requests by Democrats in Congress when Barack Obama won the 2008 presidential election.The five-member Federal Communications Commission consists of three Democrats, including Wheeler, and two Republicans.Republican Commissioner Ajit Pai is the front-runner to replace Wheeler, Macquarie Securities analyst Amy Yong said in a research note."During the last presidential transition, the commission chairman wisely heeded the will of Congress in setting aside any remaining controversial agenda items for the next Congress and administration to consider," said Republican FCC Commissioner Mike O'Rielly in a statement on Tuesday. "I thank the current leadership of both Senate and House commerce committees for calling this precedent to everyone's attention today, and expect that Chairman Wheeler will honor their request."IBD'S TAKE: Comcast stock has gained 7.5% since Donald Trump's surprise election as president on Nov. 8, and Charter stock is up, too. Learn more at IBD Stock Checkup.The FCC in October adopted new "opt-in" consumer data-privacy rules governing broadband services, giving Wheeler a win after he shelved a controversial proposal on cable-TV set-top boxes last month.Analysts expect Trump and a Republican-controlled Congress to ease up on regulation after Wheeler battled the telecom industry on broadband, internet and other issues.Business data services had been on the agenda for Thursday's FCC meeting. The FCC rules would regulate new entrants in the market — cable-TV firms such as Comcast (CMCSA) and Charter Communications (CHTR) as well as the biggest providers of business data services, including AT&T (T), Verizon Communications (VZ), and local phone companies CenturyLink (CTL) and Frontier Communications (FTR). Republicans oppose the pricing regulation.The high-speed connections are used for retail outlets, ATMs and cell towers. Smaller telecom firms such as Level 3 Communications (LVLT) and Cogent Communications (CCOI) sometimes rent the "special access" lines to serve their customers. Some renters have complained over long-term contracts and termination fees.Comcast stock rose 0.7% to close at 67.47 on the stock market today. Shares are forming a flat base with a buy point of 68.46. Charter stock also gained 0.7%, to 261.99, on Wednesday, after almost trigging the 8%-decline sell rule earlier. As AT&T (T) forges ahead with its mobile video strategy, the incoming Trump administration aims to dismantle net neutrality rules that govern internet services, say political pundits.For AT&T, the timing couldn't be better. AT&T on Wednesday launched its DirecTV Now online video streaming service. The linchpin to AT&T's mobile video strategy is allowing its wireless subscribers to stream DirecTV Now without eating into their monthly data caps.While President Obama's Federal Communications Commission has voiced concern that AT&T's DirecTV Now plans might well conflict with net neutrality, a Republican-led FCC is not likely to stand in AT&T's way.Whether broadband service providers like AT&T can favor their own services has been one of the hot potatoes in the net neutrality debate. Net neutrality rules bar internet service providers from throttling, blocking or prioritizing web traffic. Under the Obama administration, the FCC sought new regulatory authority to enforce the rules and extended them to wireless networks for the first time.IBD'S TAKE: Comcast's stock has gained 21% in 2016, with much of it coming since Trump's surprise election as President. AT&T stock, which had outperformed in the first half of 2016 amid the popularity of dividend-paying stocks, now lags. Learn more about companies that may gain from lighter regulation at IBD Stock Checkup.A Trump FCC, on the other hand, will likely favor ISPs at the expense of companies such as Alphabet's (GOOGL) Google and Netflix (NFLX), analysts say. ISPs such as Comcast (CMCSA), AT&T, Verizon Communications (VZ) and Charter Communications (CHTR) could get a boost from new revenue streams.If net neutrality rules are weakened or eliminated, ISPs might be able to charge online video services for network bandwidth usage, raising questions for web streaming services from the likes of CBS (CBS), Alphabet's YouTube and soon Hulu, or potentially Walt Disney (DIS) and Apple (AAPL), among others that might join the competition. ISPs might seek fees for "fast lane" services from content providers."We expect the idea of paying for fast lanes to be front and center in the debate," Jefferies analyst Mike McCormack told IBD. "Content providers are likely to oppose any change, though larger, well-capitalized companies could hold an advantage relative to (smaller startups) unwilling or unable to pay for fast lanes."Some observers say the stakes are big."As video becomes an increasingly important growth driver for large-scale internet platforms (Amazon.com's (AMZN) Prime, Google's YouTube, Facebook (FB) Live), the risks posed by rollback of net neutrality are magnified," Baird analyst Colin Sebastian said in a research report.While many pundits have touted a doomsday scenario for net neutrality, Trump hardly mentioned telecom policy during the campaign, so it's still uncertain if he'll seek to totally gut net neutrality. He did, however, voice opposition to AT&T's proposed acquisition of media giant Time Warner (TWX), saying it would result in too much concentration of media power in one company's hands.AT&T stock fell 3% on Friday, Oct. 21, on reports of the deal for Time Warner, which the companies announced the next day, sending AT&T shares down another 1.7% the following Monday. Since then, AT&T stock has risen 5.5%, closing Friday down a fraction, to 38.61.Also, Trump has named two net neutrality opponents to his telecom transition team. One of them, pro-business economist Jeffrey Eisenach, could be named the next FCC chairman.The agency's current senior Republican member, Ajit Pai, also is in the running, analysts say. If current FCC Chairman Tom Wheeler steps down in January, Pai could be named chairman at least on an interim basis, until the U.S. Senate holds hearings on administration appointees.Obama named his telecom transition leader, Julius Genachowski, as the new FCC chairman in March 2009. The Senate, though Democratic-controlled, didn't confirm Genachowski as chair until late June that year.Pai is a net neutrality critic and a longtime Washington insider.Oppenheimer analyst Tim Horan is cautious about sweeping changes under a new FCC in any event. He expects Republican lawmakers in Congress to play a bigger role."We believe this group (lawmakers) is significantly more dovish on the net neutrality concept than their FCC peers," said Horan in a research report. "We conclude the FCC will likely withdraw their authority to enforce net neutrality. However, we also believe that legislation will be passed that reintroduces the core tenants of net neutrality."Republicans hold a narrow majority in the Senate, so Democrats could aim to stall any net neutrality bill with a filibuster.Andy Lipman senior partner at Washington, D.C., law firm Morgan, Lewis & Bockius, says Republicans could forge a compromise with enough Senate Democrats to pass a bill that takes away the "Title II" public utility-type net neutrality rules sought by Obama's FCC while preserving core open internet tenets, such as no blocking or throttling of content.A new telecom bill might leave it up to the FCC to address issues such as fast-lane prioritization of content or "zero-rating," a regulatory term for what AT&T is doing with wireless data caps, says Lipman.In the end, that would be good for ISPs."Enforcement is at bottom discretionary," Lipman told IBD. "A Republican FCC would be less willing to micromanage sponsored data and zero-rating."Netflix stock has been among those pressured by hand-wringing over net neutrality.Netflix accounts for more than 30% of peak downstream internet traffic, making it a prime target of broadband providers for bandwidth fees, says a Baird report.During the Obama administration, Netflix pushed for stricter regulation of interconnection agreements between ISPs and programmers that operate their own content delivery networks.Interconnection deals involve internet ports, network locations where data traffic is exchanged. Netflix works with middlemen such as Level 3 Communications (LVLT) and Cogent Communications (CCOI), whose networks carry traffic between cities."Netflix already has paying arrangements in place with the major ISPs in the U.S.," said Ralph Schackart, an analyst at William Blair. "Any potential reversal of net neutrality rules by the FCC would not supersede agreements that are already established. We believe the net neutrality fears are overblown."RELATED:AT&T, Comcast, Verizon Eye Next FCC Chair, Eisenach Front-Runner?How Verizon, Comcast, Dish, T-Mobile Figure In Telecom M&A ScenariosFCC's Wheeler, At Urging Of Republicans, Pulls Controversial ItemsComcast: Does Trump Win Portend Regulatory Rollback?

Aiming to make video streaming a big driver of its mobile business, AT&T (T) laid out the nitty-gritty details of its DirecTV Now service, which will start at $35 a month for 100 channels but will go up to $60 after a promotional period ends.AT&T, after the introductory period, also will offer 60 channels for $35 monthly and 80 channels for $50 monthly. While AT&T's promotional price is aggressive, the longer-term pricing for various packages is in line with or above analyst expectations.But users that sign up for the $35 promotion has that rate for as long as they subscribe to the service.If DirecTV Now customers sign up for three months, they qualify for an Apple (AAPL) TV streaming device that normally retails for $150. Customers that commit to one month can get an Amazon.com (AMZN) Fire TV stick that starts at $40.The DirecTV Now streaming service will launch on Wednesday. AT&T did not say when the promotional period will end. AT&T will offer new customers a free, 7-day trial.IBD'S TAKE: AT&T stock, along with Verizon Communications, were top performers in the first half of 2016 owing to their dividends. Apple and Cisco Systems are other companies that are increasing shareholder returns. Learn more at IBD's Income Investor. AT&T stock was flat in after-hours trading Monday, after it revealed the details of its mobile streaming-video service."The prices are more reasonable than they had hinted at a few weeks ago," Craig Moffett, an analyst at MoffettNathanson, said in an email. "But by definition, that means that demand for the product will be lower as well."I'm sure they'll get some existing customers to trade down, but it will take some time to find out whether cord cutters are willing to pay that much for an OTT service."AT&T says it's targeting 20 million homes that do not have a pay-TV subscription currently, but the wireless video offering could attract customers of cable TV firms like Comcast (CMCSA), analysts say. With DirecTV satellite and its U-Verse service, AT&T has 25 million pay-TV customers of its own that it does not want to see switch to the lower-cost streaming package, says Jonathan Chaplin, an analyst at New Street Research, in a research report."AT&T can't undermine the economics of traditional pay-TV; they would have the most to lose if they did," Chaplin said.The DirecTV Now streaming service, though, could boost AT&T's wireless business, where growth has stalled amid continuing postpaid subscriber losses.AT&T aims to get a jump on Hulu Live, a new offering expected from the joint venture of 21st Century Fox Entertainment (FOXA), Walt Disney (DIS) and Comcast's NBC Universal. Amazon.com (AMZN) and Google-parent Alphabet (GOOGL) might also launch new streaming services with live content in 2017, analysts say.AT&T will not charge its own wireless subscribers for consuming data tied to the DirecTV Now service, a practice similar to what Verizon Communications (VZ) does with its millennial-focused Go90 service. T-Mobile US (TMUS), meanwhile, provides free streaming of Dish Network's (DISH) Sling service to its subscribers.AT&T's DirecTV Now does not provide a cloud-based DVR service and limits users to two simultaneous video streams. Dish's Sling on Monday said its customers will soon be able to record TV shows and store them online for later viewing.AT&T acquired satellite broadcaster DirecTV for $48.5 billion in 2015, gaining negotiating leverage with content providers. While Fox, Disney and NBCU have joined AT&T's programming lineup, CBS (CBS) is not part of the lineup. CBS has its own stand-alone streaming service.AT&T has stated DirecTV Now will have lower profit margins than its traditional, U-verse pay-TV services. Like other providers of so-called OTT (over-the-top) services, AT&T will not bear costs for network transport, installation or set-top boxes.Sling last week forged a deal to make its app available on Comcast set-top boxes. Analysts estimate Sling has 800,000 to 1 million subscribers.If AT&T's DirecTV Now is a big success, it could pressure Comcast and Charter Communications (CHTR) to acquire a wireless firm, perhaps T-Mobile U.S., some analysts have speculated.AT&T is seeking regulatory approval to acquire Time Warner (TWX) for $85 billion. Time Warner and its HBO, as well as content from Viacom (VIA), A&E, Discovery and Starz, are part of DirecTV Now's channel package. HBO will cost $5 extra per month, down from its usual $10 to $15 fee.RELATED:AT&T Swallows Razor-Thin Margins On $35 Video Streaming DealHulu Live Service Gets Fox And Disney, Waiting On CBS, NBCUJohn Malone Talks Up Apple Buy Of Disney, Likes AT&T Strategy

Shares of Comcast (CMCSA) and Charter Communications (CHTR) rose Wednesday as analysts speculated President-elect Donald Trump and a Republican-controlled Congress could ease up on regulation after current FCC Chairman Tom Wheeler battled the industry on broadband and other issues.Comcast stock was up 1.5% and Charter stock 2.9% in the stock market today. Shares of Cable One (CABO) were down 1%.Wheeler has been at odds with the cable-TV industry over internet regulation and so-called net neutrality rules; broadband data privacy; opening up the set-top box market to more competition; and specialized business services."If the rhetoric of those surrounding Trump's campaign rings true, we can expect a Republican FCC to make a big push to roll back some of the regulations put in place under President Obama, such as the Title II/net neutrality rules," said Jennifer Fritzsche, a Well Fargo analyst, in a research report. The Obama administration's Department of Justice filed an antitrust lawsuit Wednesday against AT&T (T), charging that its DirecTV business engaged in unlawful information-sharing with other pay TV operators amid former Time Warner Cable's efforts to seek carriage fees for a Los Angles-area sports network carrying Dodgers baseball games.The DOJ filing comes 10 days after AT&T announced its proposed $85.4 billion acquisition of media giant Time Warner (TWX), which analysts say faces regulatory hurdles. AT&T acquired satellite broadcaster DirecTV in 2015."We respect the DOJ's important role in protecting consumers, but in this case, which occurred before AT&T's acquisition of DirecTV, we see the facts differently," said David McAtee, AT&T general counsel, in a statement.  "The reason why no other major TV provider chose to carry this content was that no one wanted to force all of their customers to pay the inflated prices that Time Warner Cable was demanding for a channel devoted solely to L.A. Dodgers baseball."We make our carriage decisions independently, legally and only after thorough negotiations with the content owner."Charter Communications (CHTR) acquired Time Warner Cable in 2015. TWC spent over $7 billion in 2013 to acquire rights to Dodger games, beating out Rupert Murdoch's 21st Century Fox (FOXA).IBD'S TAKE: AT&T stock has shed 16% since Oct. 1 amid speculation over rising interest rates and reaction to the Time Warner takeover bid. Look for news about other dividend paying stocks at The Income Investor.In 2011, Time Warner Cable had doled out an estimated $3 billion for rights to L.A. Lakers basketball games.Time Warner launched a L.A. sports network in 2014. Many pay TV providers claimed carriage fees sought by Time Warner Cable were too high, and did not carry the Dodgers channel.The Justice Department lawsuit alleges that DirecTV was the "ringleader" of an effort involving then rival AT&T as well as Cox Communications and Charter to undermine negotiations with Time Warner Cable.Federal regulators blocked Comcast's (CMCSA) proposed acquisition of Time Warner Cable in 2015.AT&T stock edged down a fraction in the stock market today to 36.37.RELATED:AT&T CEO On Time Warner Deal: Aiming To Set Pace In Innovation
