The media industry is "likely one more deal away from potentially reshaping the landscape for at least a decade," said Barclays analysts in a lengthy dissection of the entertainment and telecom sectors following confirmation of the $85.4 billion merger of AT&T (T) and Time Warner (TWX).But there are a number of other scenarios in play, especially with CBS (CBS) and Viacom (VIAB) being forcefully nudged toward merger talks by Sumner Redstone's National Amusements, and even reports of Disney (DIS) potentially being interested in Netflix (NFLX).Could the latter be the landscape-changing deal?The House of Mouse, which owns ABC, ESPN, Marvel, Lucasfilm and has an investment in streamer BAMTech, is missing a key direct-to-consumer business, in Barclays' view, and its streaming efforts aren't coming soon enough to help offset ESPN's subscriber-loss issues.Streaming heavyweight Netflix would significantly bolster Disney's distribution and technological capabilities, Barclays said.But such a combination is unlikely, according to media reports. And comments from Disney CEO Bob Iger about the complementary, supplemental nature of an online ESPN-branded channel point to the conglomerate wanting to keep its premium cable network a sports destination and a valued cable-bundle component."We have no misconceptions about how disruptive the deal could be to the Disney culture given a potentially toxic mix of Hollywood and technology mindsets having to coexist," said Barclays. "However, we believe if there was ever a time to take this risk, it would probably be now given that technology players are for the first time outlining a real vision around video instead of the small scale experiments thus far. "It added that such a merger would be "a defining moment for the media industry," bringing together the top media company and the original streaming disrupter and potentially "reshaping the industry for decades into the future."Shares of Disney closed up 0.4% at 93.37 on the stock market today, falling just short of their 50-day after and hitting resistance at that key level of support for a second straight session. Netflix dipped 0.1%, after jumping 3.4% Friday, when news of the AT&T-Time Warner deal broke.IBD'S TAKE: Is Netflix still a tech company or a media company? The answer to that question may affect any price tag for Netflix as the two sectors converge.But a Disney-Netflix deal isn't the only move that would reshape the industry.Barclays sees a not-too-distant future, five to seven years in the making, in which three or four vertically integrated media conglomerates fight for share among themselves and online competitors."With Comcast (CMCSA) getting into wireless and AT&T getting into content, Comcast's and AT&T's business models may become indistinguishable in the coming years, especially if 5G makes fixed wireless video delivery a real possibility," said Barclays."We believe Charter (CHTR) and Verizon (VZ) are the other two companies that have the opportunity to reach this end state given their scales in wireline and wireless, respectively."RELATED:Consumer Groups Knock AT&T-Time Warner MergerHow Aggressive AT&T Has Out-Maneuvered Verizon, ComcastNBCUniversal Doubles BuzzFeed Bet As Old Media Seeks New GrowthNetflix Countersues, Slams 21st Century Fox 'Involuntary Servitude'Disney, Salesforce Didn't Bid On Twitter Because Of 'Haters'

T-Mobile US (TMUS) stock hit a nine-year high Monday as Q3 earnings topped views, the company raised guidance and speculation of wireless industry M&A heated up in the wake of AT&T's (T) proposed acquisition of Time Warner (TWX).Asked about the AT&T-Time Warner deal on T-Mobile's earnings conference call, T-Mobile CEO John Legere said: "It's a bold move. It's going to cause acceleration. It's good for T-Mobile in the short and medium term."Analysts say Comcast (CMCSA) could speed up its push into wireless, perhaps by acquiring T-Mobile in partnership with Charter Communications (CHTR). Both Comcast and Charter have agreements to lease access to Verizon Communications' (VZ) wireless network. But Legere said that's not a viable long-term strategy.IBD'S TAKE: T-Mobile stock gapped past a 48.21 flat-base buy point in fast turnover to mark a nine-year high. Learn more at IBD Stock Checkup.Some analysts say regulators now might be more open to a Sprint (S) merger with T-Mobile, as AT&T grows larger through the acquisitions of satellite TV broadcaster DirecTV and now media giant Time Warner — if regulators approve that latter deal. Telecom industry merger talks, though, are on hold until the completion of a government auction of radio spectrum.Legere said AT&T could become "further defocused" on wireless as it invests in new businesses. "There's upside for us" in subscriber growth, he said."There is a piece of the industry of the future that they (AT&T) are attempting to define," added Legere. "(AT&T CEO Stephenson) Randall's short version is something I've been saying for a long time, that video is going mobile and mobile is going video."He says regulators will prevent AT&T from using Time Warner's content exclusively on its networks.T-Mobile on Monday reported higher-than-expected Q3 profit and raised full-year EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization) guidance as its wireless subscriber additions again led the industry.Shares of the "Uncarrier"-branded wireless firm jumped 9.5% in the stock market today, to 51.19, their highest price since August 2007."Despite T-Mobile's consistently strong operating story, people will inevitably focus on M&A," said Craig Moffett, an analyst at MoffettNathanson, in a research report.T-Mobile said Q3 earnings minus items jumped 80% from the year-earlier quarter to 27 cents. Analysts had modeled 22 cents. Revenue rose 18% to $9.2 billion vs. consensus estimates of $9.43 billion.T-Mobile forecast full-year adjusted EBITDA of $10.2 billion to $10.4 billion, up from its earlier guidance of $9.95 billion at the midpoint of its range.Apple (AAPL) rolled out the iPhone 7 in September, and T-Mobile and Sprint ramped up "free" iPhone trade-in promotions, grabbing share from AT&T and Verizon."The EBITDA guidance raise is an incremental positive to T-Mobile's profitability and FCF story," said Jennifer Fritzsche, a Wells Fargo analyst, in a report. "The slight top-line miss was due to lower-than-expected equipment revenue, which we believe was partially due to TMUS' 'free' iPhone 7 promotion in September."Bellevue, Wash.-based T-Mobile added 851,000 postpaid phone lines in Q3, about the same as in Q3 2015. Sprint added 347,000 postpaid phone lines in Q3, the company preannounced last week, with full earnings out Tuesday. AT&T lost 268,000 postpaid phone lines, while Verizon shed 36,000 postpaid phone lines.RELATED:How Aggressive AT&T Has Out-Maneuvered Verizon, ComcastConsumer Groups Knock AT&T-Time Warner Merger

In just the past year and a half, antitrust concerns have undone or jeopardized several merger deals, adding to doubts that AT&T (T) can consummate its $85.4 billion takeover of Time Warner (TWX).AT&T agreed to pay $107.50 a share for Time Warner, but the media giant's stock fell 3.1% to 86.74 on the stock market today, well below the bid price and an indication investors are skeptical that the deal will go through. AT&T fell 1.7% to 36.68. Still, the companies see the deal closing in late 2017.The Obama administration has become more aggressive on mergers and acquisitions lately, either suing to block them or demanding conditions that were too onerous to accept. Donald Trump has said he would block an AT&T-Time Warner deal as president, while Hillary Clinton has voiced concerns.In February  2014, Comcast (CMCSA) agreed to buy Time Warner Cable for $45 billion, combining the top two cable and broadband providers. The Federal Communications Commission raised concerns, with consumer groups and Netflix (NFLX) also objecting. With regulators expected to block the deal outright, Comcast gave up in April 2015.Charter Communications (CHTR) moved in, agreeing in May 2015 to buy TWC. That deal closed in May 2016.In November 2015, Pfizer (PFE) reached a deal to buy Allergan (AGN) for $160 billion in a so-called tax inversion that would've allowed Pfizer to change its domicile to Ireland and slash its tax bill.The deal, which would've created the world's largest drugmaker, came at a time when politicians were already bashing tax inversions. The Treasury Department introduced a series of new rules that made inversions less attractive.In April, Pfizer walked away from the deal, citing the Treasury rules.RELATED:Forget Allergan: Pfizer Has Its Sights On This Cancer Drugmaker Allergan, Pfizer Strike Off Down Separate Paths After Merger Killed As crude prices were collapsing in November 2014, oilfield services provider Halliburton (HAL) agreed to buy rival Baker Hughes (BHI) in a deal that was worth $34.6 billion at the time. It also would've put the combined companies above Schlumberger (SLB), prompting regulators to warn of a duopoly.Halliburton scrambled to find buyers for assets it sought to shed to win regulatory approval. But the Justice Department reportedly pushed Halliburton to sell more than $7.5 billion in assets to a single buyer.Then in April, the DOJ filed a lawsuit to block the merger, and in May the companies called off the deal, which by then was worth about $28 billion.RELATED:Why Halliburton's Failed Buyout May Actually Hurt CompetitionHalliburton Eyes New Deals After Ending Baker Hughes Bid In February 2015, Staples (SPLS) agreed to buy Office Depot (ODP) for $6 billion as the retailers faced pressure from e-commerce rivals like Amazon (AMZN).It was their second attempt. An earlier one was blocked by the Federal Trade Commission in 1997, but Staples and Office Depot said this time was different because the industry landscape was completely different, citing Amazon and other competitors.The FTC disagreed and sued in December 2015. In May, a judge sided with the federal government.In September 2014, General Electric (GE) inked an agreement to sell its home appliance business to Electrolux (ELUXY) for $3.3 billion as the industrial conglomerate sought to shed noncore assets and focus on areas like aviation, power systems, and oil and gas.The DOJ sued in July 2015, saying the merger would hurt consumers. Before a judge could rule on the lawsuit, GE walked away in December. The next month, GE sold the unit to China's Haier for $5.4 billion.In December 2013, top food distributor Sysco (SYY) agreed to buy rival US Foods for $3.5 billion. In February 2015, the FTC sued, arguing that a merger of the No. 1 and No. 2 players in the market would result in higher prices for restaurants, hotels and other companies that buy food and related supplies.In June 2015, Sysco abandoned the deal after a judge ruled in favor of the FTC.In July 2015, Anthem (ANTM) said it would buy Cigna (CI) for $54 billion, creating the largest health insurer by membership. It came just three weeks after Aetna (AET) reached a deal to acquire Humana (HUM) for $37 billion. The consolidation efforts came as the health sector struggled to find savings and address higher-than-anticipated costs associated with ObamaCare mandates.In July, the DOJ filed lawsuits to block both deals, saying much of the U.S. health insurance market would be controlled by just three companies. But in August, the DOJ signaled it might be willing to reach a settlement with Anthem and Cigna to allow their merger.In October 2015, Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA) said it plans to buy Rite Aid (RAD) for $17 billion, bringing together the No. 2 and No. 3 drugstore chains and leapfrogging No. 1 CVS Health (CVS).Walgreens has been looking for buyers who could help the company offload stores and pass regulatory muster. Management is also in talks with the FTC and appeared to be making progress this summer.But Kroger (KR) seems unwilling to buy hundreds of stores that Walgreens and Rite Aid are trying to divest. Kroger had been interested, but wanted to close the locations and reopen them in its grocery stores. The FTC wants to preserve the stand-alone drugstores, sources told the New York Post.

Companies that sell internet access would need subscribers' permission before using or sharing sensitive information including web browsing history under a proposal announced Thursday by the Federal Communications Commission.The agency is to vote Oct. 27 on the plan by Chairman Tom Wheeler, a Democrat, to set rules that have been resisted by internet service providers led by AT&T (T) and top U.S. cable provider Comcast (CMCSA)."The information you share with your broadband provider is yours," Wheeler said in a blog post. "With the FCC's new privacy protections, you will have the right to determine how it's used."IBD'S TAKE: A day after partnering with IBM, AT&T is "netbonding" with Amazon Web Services.AT&T, Verizon Communications (VZ), Comcast and fellow cable provider Charter Communications (CHTR) see that Alphabet (GOOGL) unit Google and Facebook (FB) have amassed riches by profiling web users and selling targeted advertisements, and they want to get into the game, too. Verizon, for instance, is gaining a toehold in the $187 billion digital advertising market with its purchase of Yahoo (YHOO).The FCC has authority over telephone and cable companies. Privacy practices of other companies, including web giants Facebook and Alphabet's Google, are regulated by the Federal Trade Commission.RELATED:AT&T, Comcast Cheer: FCC's Wheeler Pulls Set-Top Vote

The drum roll goes on for AT&T's (T) launch of "DirecTV Now," an 100-plus-channel Internet video service, as the industry waits for AT&T to announce its pricing for the service.AT&T is expected to launch DirecTV Now this quarter.How much cable TV rivals such as Comcast (CMCSA) and Charter Communications (CHTR) need to worry about the DirecTV Now launch depends a lot on its pricing.And AT&T's pricing also could impact the strategies of Hulu, which is expected to launch a new live streaming TV service in early 2017; Amazon.com (AMZN), Google (GOOGL) and other new entrants in the so-called OTT, or over-the-top, video market."If they price too aggressively, there is an obvious risk of cannibalization," MoffettNathanson analyst Craig Moffett said via email. "They make very attractive margins on their legacy DTV business today."Offering an internet-based alternative will mean lower costs, particularly for equipment, so they can justify a lower price. But that doesn't mean they can justify pricing at razor thin margins. That would be cutting off their nose to spite their face."Nomura Securities weighed in on Friday, saying AT&T might bite the bullet on mid-single-digit profit margins and sell DirecTV Now for $55 monthly. UBS analyst John Hodulik earlier estimated that AT&T could sell DirecTV Now for $50 a month."We view DirecTV Now as a potential game-changer, but with two caveats: The customer is not locked into a contract and Hulu is expected to launch a competing OTT product in early 2017," Nomura analyst Jeffrey Kvaal said in a research report Friday.Hulu's live streaming service is expected to cost around $40 a month.IBD'S TAKE: High-dividend paying stocks such as AT&T and Verizon have cooled off amid talk that interest rates may rise. Some large cap companies, such as Facebook or Edwards Lifesciences, offer faster growth. Check out the IBD Big Cap 20.Hulu is a joint venture of 21st Century Fox Entertainment (FOXA), Walt Disney (DIS)and Comcast. Time Warner (TWX) recently bought a 10% stake in Hulu.At a Goldman Sachs conference in September, AT&T CEO Randall Stephenson said DirecTV Now will roll out at a "very, very aggressive price point. Stephenson said AT&T will accept thinner margins than usual in the pay TV business.Still, there's wiggle room in AT&T's comments because DirecTV Now has been described at a fat bundle, with a lot of content, not a skinny bundle with fewer channels. AT&T announced plans for DirecTV Now in January.Programming will be AT&T's biggest cost. AT&T has lined up content from most media firms, with the exception of CBS (CBS) and 21st Century Fox Entertainment, analysts say. But there may be other costs.William Power, an analyst at William Blair, says AT&T might use Akamai Technologies' (AKAM) content delivery network to whisk Internet video to homes.Akamai's services might be needed because AT&T's DirecTV Now will stream live TV, including sports. AT&T will provide one or two data streams per household. For wireless customers, DirecTV Now usage will not count toward monthly data caps.UBS estimates DirecTV Now could have 2.5 million customers by 2020. Hodulik is cautious on forecasts because OTT competition will likely heat up."We believe Amazon is well underway with developing a linear TV service, and we doubt that Apple (AAPL) has permanently shelved its plans," he said in a research report.AT&T stock fell 0.6% to 38.87 in the stock market today.RELATED:AT&T Downgraded On Apple iPhone Competition, Comcast Wireless EntryIPhone 7 Bottom Line: 'Apple's Gain, Carriers' Pain'

Gap (GPS), meanwhile, gapped up over its 50- and 200-day moving averages, rising 15% after the company reported better-than-expected sales in September. Deutsche Bank upgraded shares to hold from sell.Arris International (ARRS) also bucked the trend, rising nearly 7% to 29.65. Arris struck a deal with Charter Communications (CHTR) that gives Charter a warrant to purchase up to 6 million shares of Arris stock, but only after Charter buys a certain amount of products from Arris.Alcoa (AA) kicks of Q3 earnings season in the coming week when it reports Tuesday before the open. The aluminum giant is above its 50-day moving average as it works on a shallow, cup-shaped base with a 33.01 buy point. Shares of Arris International (ARRS), the No. 1 maker of set-top boxes offered by traditional pay-TV companies, rose Monday as analysts said the FCC's efforts to open up the set-top market won't have much impact on Arris for years, if ever.Arris stock fell 5% Friday — knocking it down from near a potential buy point — after FCC Chairman Tom Wheeler unveiled the agency's latest proposal to open up the market. The new proposal backs away from the FCC's original idea of forcing cable, telecom and satellite pay-TV providers to stream video to Roku, Apple's (AAPL) Apple TV and other makers of third-party set-tops. Instead, it requires the pay-TV companies provide apps through which their programming can be obtained through the third-party set-tops.The FCC is set to vote on the proposal on Sept. 29. It's a little more friendly to Comcast (CMCSA), Verizon Communications (VZ), AT&T (T) and the other pay-TV providers, but still has the potential to open up the market.IBD'S TAKE: Arris stock last week almost reached a buy point of 29.04 out of a cup-with-handle base. Shares showed support at the key 50-day line. It's important to be able to read the most common chart patterns, a skill you can master at IBD University.Still, Needham and RBC Capital Markets maintained buy and outperform ratings, respectively, on Arris stock, in research reports released Monday and late Friday. Needham analyst Richard Valera and RBC's Mitch Steves both pointed out that the cable companies would have two years to develop the apps and that it could be much longer because of likely litigation.Moreover, they said there is a solid chance the FCC won't approve the change, and they said the pay-TV boxes still would likely perform much more seamlessly.Approval, however, is expected. "We find it hard to spin it as anything but a win for consumers and negative for providers of traditional video (set-top boxes) like ARRS," wrote Valera.He also said Arris, in any case, has a "seat at the table" with the third-party boxes, through its acquisition last year of ActiveVideo, which provides such software. Arris bought ActiveVideo for $135 million in partnership with cable firm Charter Communications (CHTR).Friday's stock "pullback was overdone," wrote RBC's Steves.Arris stock rose 1.2% in the stock market today, to 27.06. But the stock has fallen more than 25% since touching a 16-year high above 37 in April 2015.Steves has a price target of 33 on Arris stock, while Valera has a target of 32.In August, Arris promoted 17-year company veteran Bruce McClelland to CEO, with CEO Bob Sanzione becoming executive chairman.

Do you invest as successfully as Fidelity Investments does? Would it help your game to know in which large-cap stocks Fidelity's approximately 200 stock and stock-plus-bond mutual funds made some of their biggest second-quarter adds to and sells from?Todd Rosenbluth, S&P Global Market Intelligence director of mutual fund research, pored through the newly released SEC holdings disclosure of the second-largest mutual fund manager and compared it with past filings by the Boston-based behemoth, which had $1.4 trillion in long-term assets as of June 30.The snapshot of Q2 trades gives insight into what stocks Fidelity managers thought were worth getting into and what they were willing to trim.Information technology remained the fund giant's largest sector, with 23% of its collective assets as of June 30. That was the case even though many Fidelity managers sold shares in two tech titans, Microsoft (MSFT) and Apple (AAPL), in the second quarter. Fidelity trimmed its Microsoft share count by 20% compared with its Q1 stake. It peeled Apple back by 6.9%.Microsoft's stock fell 7% in Q2, but has rallied 13% since June 30. No word yet on whether Fidelity resumed buying.Apple's shares sank 12% in Q2, but have rallied 14% since then.In contrast, Fidelity beefed up its shares in home entertainment software stock Activision Blizzard (ATVI) by 92%. "In Feburary 2016, ATVI completed its purchase of King Digital and reported first and second quarter results ahead of the Capital IQ consensus," Rosenbluth reported to clients. On Thursday afternoon shares were about where they closed at the end of Q2.The stock ended June 17% higher than where it began the quarter. It's been about flat since then.In the health care sector, Fidelity was both a net buyer and seller.Fidelity liked the prognosis for biotech firm Vertex Pharmaceuticals (VRTX) enough to graft an additional 48% onto its existing share count. That turned out to be a good call. In July, Vertex got FDA approval for a new cystic fibrosis drug, Rosenbluth notes. Now shares are up 15% since the end of Q2.Going in the other director, Fidelity sliced 18% from its Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) stake and 3.8% from its UnitedHealth Group (UNH) holding. Both are about where they ended Q2.In other sectors, Fidelity added to its stakes in cell-tower owner American Tower (AMT), cable provider Charter Communications (CHTR) and carmaker Tesla Motors (TSLA). Fidelity added 20% to its positions in each.American Tower is about where it was on June 30. Charter is up 11%. The stock is seeing solid earnings estimate revision activity from analysts, says Zacks Equity Research. Still, Charter's telecom services-integrated industry group is ranked 66, down from 43 four weeks ago.Tesla is up fractionally from where it closed Q2.Among stocks that Fidelity trimmed in Q2 were Amazon (AMZN), cut by 1.3%, and Visa (V), shaved by 1.9%.Fidelity's largest stock mutual funds continue to hold many of the largest megacap stocks, even those that the fund family as a group trimmed in Q2, Rosenbluth said. The $19.4 billion Blue Chip Growth (FBGRX) has top-10 holdings in Apple and Visa. Other top 10 stocks included Tesla, which the complex added to.Blue Chip Growth is up 1.96% this year going into Thursday, vs. 3.42% for its large-cap growth peers tracked by Morningstar Inc. and 8.29% for the S&P 500.The $7.5 billion Dividend Growth (FDGFX) held trim targets Apple, Johnson & Johnson and Microsoft. Dividend Growth is up 5.02% this year.In separate data, Morningstar Inc. highlights stocks that funds have added to recently. The $109 billion Fidelity Contrafund (FCNTX), managed by Will Danoff since 1990, has interesting adds.Contrafund, which is among the largest stock mutual funds available, has added to B2Gold. The Canadian-based gold producer runs mines globally. As of midday Friday, shares were up 209% so far this year.Earnings per share grew 95%, 69%, 46% and 52% the past four quarters. But note that the shares are trading just above 4 and have never reached 5.Contrafund holds about a dozen mining stocks and has boosted its stakes recently in half of them.Itau Unibanco (ITUB) is another name in which Contrafund has raised its stake. The Brazilian bank holding company's ADRs are up 73% so far this year.EPS has declined for six quarters in a row, but analysts see expect a 4% gain in the current quarter and a 5% increase in 2017.The company has a so-so Composite Rating from IBD of 78. The Composite Rating, which starts at 1 and runs to 99, combines IBD's five performance ratings, including EPS and Relative Price Strength Ratings. Stocks poised to move higher often have a high Comp Rating. You should look for stocks whose rating is 95 or higher, which means that they've outperformed 95% of all other stocks in terms of their Composite Rating.IBD'S TAKE: Alan Elliot explains why a high Comp Rating is not always a buy signal.Itau also has IBD's SMR Rating of B. SMR Ratings of A and B are the best.And Contrafund opened a stake in Applied Materials (AMAT) as of its latest disclosure.EPS went from a 4% decline three quarters ago to 17% and 52% growth in the two most recent frames.That 52% EPS gain was reported for Q3 on Thursday and it topped Wall Street expectations.But Applied's Q3 revenue, up 13%, were slightly below analysts' consensus. The maker of chipmaking equipment posted revenue of $2.82 billion in the period, falling short of Street forecasts. Six analysts surveyed by Zacks expected $2.84 billion.For the current quarter ending in October, Applied Materials expects its per-share earnings to range from 61 cents to 69 cents.The stock gapped up 7% on huge volume Friday. The semiconductor equipment maker's shares are up 58% so far this year.

Google's decision to rethink its broadband services strategy is a plus for AT&T (T), Comcast (CMCSA) and Charter Communications (CHTR), but it's much too early for entrenched internet service providers to declare victory.Google-parent Alphabet (GOOGL) is putting plans to expand super-fast fiber optic services on hold while it explores less-expensive wireless technologies. The Google Fiber service for now remains available in just five markets.The Federal Communications Commission plans to open up a swath of unlicensed airwaves in the 3.5 GHz frequency band. Google has been testing wireless broadband using those airwaves.Google Fiber provides internet speeds of 1 gigabit per second and above, with connections that are highly reliable. Does a Google-branded wireless broadband service now pose less of a threat to AT&T, Comcast, Charter, Verizon Communications (VZ) and other ISPs?"I think it is too early to draw that conclusion," Blair Levin, former chief of staff to the FCC chairman, told IBD. "If wireless works for Google, the number of places where it could deploy a faster, better, cheaper network would expand greatly, expanding the level of threat.""Cable is certainly in the strongest position, but whether Google's announcement represents a diminished or greater threat is still unknown and depends largely on what ... deployment costs and service quality turns out to be," said Levin, also former director of the FCC's National Broadband Plan.Craig Moffett, an analyst at MoffettNathanson, has a similar view."It's hard to say whether this is a genuine pullback or whether it is simply a pause to consider alternative technologies. At the very least, this will slow things down for a while, since testing wireless alternatives will take a fair amount of time," Moffett told IBD."It's still too early to say whether wireless will pose a significant threat to wired broadband. That's certainly the intent, and it works well in controlled lab settings, but we're still in the early days," said Moffett. "There are still a lot more questions than answers about how it will perform in the real world."IBD'S TAKE: A Q2 beat propelled Alphabet stock to a new high, and it's a member of the IBD Big Cap 20. These stocks can make big gains with less volatility than smaller caps. Tech names have made the list as of late.Google in June acquired Webpass, which provides fixed wireless broadband services in San Francisco, San Diego, Miami, Chicago, Boston and Oakland, Calif."The current delay either means the 3.5 (GHz) spectrum is ready for real testing and/or fiber is more expensive than they thought," added Levin, now a nonresident fellow at the Brookings Institution. "I think it is still unknown whether Google will be successful, but the last several months suggest a combination of new thinking and course corrections to achieve the goal of deploying faster, better, cheaper networks."Google Fiber is available in parts of Austin, Texas; Provo, Utah; Kansas City, Mo., and neighboring Kansas City, Kan.; as well as San Antonio. Google announced plans early in 2015 to expand the service to Nashville, Tenn.; Atlanta; Charlotte, N.C.; Raleigh-Durham, N.C.; and Salt Lake City. Google has also touted plans to expand its fiber-based services to large cities, perhaps including Chicago or Los Angeles.Alphabet stock was down 0.6 to 801.19 at the close on the stock market today, but shares touched an all-time high of 813.88 on Thursday and were up 18% from late June.

To learn more about how technical analysis can help improve your investment results, visit this lesson in IBD University.Nasdaq 100 component and IBD 50 name Broadcom (AVGO) continued to make progress after a low-volume breakout over a 163.87 cup-with-handle buy point. Yirendai reports after the close.On the downside, new issue Wayfair (W) plunged 19% after the company reported a wider-than-expected loss (a loss of 43 cents a share vs. a 15 cent loss a year earlier) but another quarter of strong sales growth, up 60%. When AT&T (T), Verizon Communications (VZ), Comcast (CMCSA) and Google-parent Alphabet (GOOGL) report earnings, there's a good reason why analysts that follow Dycom Industries (DY) sit up and take notice.Dycom, an installer of fiber-optic wiring, has prospered as phone and cable TV companies hurry to deploy super-fast, one gigabit-per-second internet services to homes. Dycom digs small trenches where fiber-optic wiring is buried, breaks up and repairs sidewalks if needed, or strings the fiber wiring aerially to homes and business via utility poles.AT&T, Verizon, Comcast and Google, as well as CenturyLink (CTL), are Dycom's biggest customers. Any updates on the capital spending plans of phone and cable TV firms are key for Dycom. If new projects are signaled on earnings calls, Dycom and rivals rev up to bid on contracts in local markets.Web video is driving the need for faster internet speeds now, with virtual reality expected to push broadband speeds higher. There's plenty of talk about faster, fifth-generation wireless networks, but fiber optic broadband speeds are forecast to evolve from 1 gigabit -- or 1 billion bits of information -- per second to 10 gigabits per second."As much as everyone thinks about wireless usage, people are realizing the need for fatter pipes in the ground, and the foundation of that plumbing is fiber," said Jennifer Fritzsche, analyst at Wells Fargo.Dycom's stock has climbed more than 20% in 2016, with surging revenue from telecom customers driving earnings growth.Internet companies like Google rely on fast broadband connections. Aiming to pressure telecom firms into upgrading broadband networks to higher speeds, Google has ramped up its own superfast fiber-optic services to homes and businesses.Dycom management has never named Alphabet as a customer. Analysts contend, though, that Alphabet is Dycom's "unnamed" customer in earnings releases and accounted for 7% of fiscal-third-quarter revenue.Where Google is heading with its broadband strategy has been a worry for Dycom shareholders. On Alphabet's second-quarter earnings call in July, Chief Financial Officer Ruth Porat said it may use innovative wireless technologies to speed up its roll-out of gigabit internet services. In early August, Alphabet said it would put on hold plans to expand Google Fiber to new markets.Right now, Google Fiber is available only in San Antonio; Austin, Texas; Provo, Utah; Kansas City, Mo., and neighboring Kansas City, Kan.  Alphabet plans to test wireless broadband in up to 24 markets over the next 18 months.Dycom stock fell last week on the news over Google's building "pause". But, some analysts say there's still plenty growth coming from AT&T, Verizon, CenturyLink and Comcast. And, Fritzsche says Google will need to deploy some fiber-optic plant in neighborhoods, even if wireless links reach homes directly.IBD'S TAKE: Dycom gapped out of a cup-with-handle base after reporting earnings in late May, jumping into IBD's Leaderboard for a while.  Shares fell below its 50-day moving average last week amid speculation over Google's plans. Dycom is No. 2 on  IBD's Telecom-Infrastructure group with a 96 Composite Rating, just behind Ubiquiti Networks.AT&T has touted plans to expand its GigaPower broadband service to some 12.5 million homes and businesses by the end of 2019. In January, AT&T signaled it may target 14 million homes or more, up from its current 2.2 million.More than 26% of Dycom's first-quarter revenue came from AT&T alone. In the first quarter, AT&T revenue rose 70% to $178 million.To hit or exceed its 2019 goals for GigaPower, AT&T needs to step on the accelerator, says Adam Thalhimer, analyst at BB&T Capital Markets. AT&T plans to expand GigaPower from 20 markets to 56 markets across the country."If you look at the math, it's suggesting some very intense construction years in 2017 and 2018, and Dycom should benefit," Thalhimer said.Then there's Verizon. On its first-quarter call in April, Verizon touted plans to expand its FiOS services to Boston and, perhaps, other East Coast cities. The FiOS network now reaches 18 million homes and buildings, but Verizon had stopped expanding that service in 2010.And don't forget Comcast, which was Dycom's second-biggest customer in its fiscal third quarter. Aside from its consumer-focused gigabit push, Comcast has been expanding its high-speed internet network to small and medium-sized businesses. Dycom's second-quarter revenue from Comcast rose 47% to $96 million.Charter Communications (CHTR) is another customer ramping up business services. Cable TV firms in general are pushing optical fiber deeper into networks, replacing the old "coaxial" lines.Analysts say there's also upside for Dycom from the Connect America Fund program -- federal government funding aimed at bringing speedier broadband services to rural areas. On Dycom's first-quarter earnings call, Nielsen described it as a $150 million to $200 million annual opportunity through 2020. Phone companies that get Connect America funding include AT&T, Frontier Communications (FTR), CenturyLink and Windstream (WIN).One issue for investors, though, is whether the potential upside from companies deploying super-fast internet services is already built into Dycom's stock. Short interest in Dycom stock is high.On Dycom's fiscal third-quarter earnings call, Chief Executive Steven Nielsen said Dycom's revenue from the gigabit gold mine hasn't peaked."We're in the early stages," he said, referring to a new upgrade cycle in wireline networks. Nielsen wasn't available for an interview.Analysts look at Dycom's backlog to sift out data on new contracts. Dycom ended its fiscal third quarter with a total backlog of $5.65 billion, up 97% from a year earlier, and a 12-month backlog of $2.2 billion, up 37%."Backlog has been inflecting very positively over the past couple of quarters, the trend is good," said Bobby Burleson, analyst  at Canaccord Genuity. "Backlog is projects that have been bid and won. Eventually they come off backlog as projects go live. It might take three years to complete. It's a forward indicator of revenue."Another issue for investors is whether Dycom's EBITDA -- earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization -- will shrink as the company adds labor and equipment for new projects. Working capital costs rise as it wins new business. With 12,500 employees, Dycom could add thousands more over the next three to four years, some analysts say."What we've said, and what we've executed against, is that we think a mid-teens EBITDA business is attainable," CEO Nielsen said on Dycom's first-quarter call.Based in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., Dycom is slated to report fiscal-fourth-quarter earnings in late August. Dycom's profit should jump 60% to $1.55 per share, with revenue growing 33% to $771 million, according to analysts polled by Thomson Reuters.Phone companies account for nearly two-thirds of Dycom's revenue, and cable TV firms makes up about one-fourth. Dycom also performs construction, engineering and maintenance services for electric and gas utilities and other customers.Dycom competes with Mastec (MTZ), Emcor Group (EME) and many small, local specialty contractors. But Dycom is a more specialized contractor than bigger Mastec."Dycom sticks to what they know best, which is telecom networks," BB&T's Thalhimer said.

With Netflix (NFLX) posting a big miss on subscriber additions for the second quarter, pay TV proponents may be breathing a sigh of relief. And as the video streaming service's stock crumbles, two cable giants -- Comcast (CMCSA) and Charter Communications (CHTR) -- are showing compelling chart action ahead of their quarterly reports.UBS said Tuesday that its recent survey showed that satisfaction with most aspects of the pay TV "big bundle" remain high, including customer experience, channel choice and customer service.But it's still good to keep in mind that one of the biggest reasons consumers cut the cord -- monthly cost -- received the lowest score out of all the metrics, with only 44% of those in the pay TV survey saying they were very or somewhat satisfied. And while cord-cutting fears have eased since the middle of last year, the analyst notes that those fears remain an "overhang" in the long term.UBS believes cable companies Comcast and Charter are best positioned as content migrates to nontraditional screens, saying cable provides the fastest in-home connections as well as in-home and out-of-home Wi-Fi.Comcast rose 0.3% to 67.09 Tuesday. The stock recently broke out to new highs after consolidating for a year. Shares are still trading in buy range past an entry at 65.09, and are just 1% below their July 12 high. Comcast reports quarterly earnings on July 27.IBD'S TAKE: Comcast is ranked No. 2 in the Telecom Services-Cable/Satellite industry group with a Composite Rating of 84 out of 99. But we can see using IBD Stock Checkup tool that the group is a laggard at No. 153 of the 197 groups that IBD tracks, and top stocks typically come out of the top quartile of IBD's groups. To find highly rated stocks from the best industry groups, check out Leaderboard.Charter is trading 3% below its recent high, reached after the stock broke out of a flat base with a 233.80 buy point. Shares struggled to hold within buy range Tuesday, losing 1%, but trading volume was light. Charter will issue its quarterly report on Aug. 9.Industry peers Verizon (VZ) and T-Mobile (TMUS) are trying to take advantage of the cord-cutting trend.Verizon has a mobile streaming service called Go90, which includes original series and sports. And T-Mobile allows its customers to stream unlimited video from YouTube Netflix, HBO and others for free with Binge On.Verizon is still trading in buy range after breaking out of a cup base in late June. It's just 2% below its recent peak, losing 0.4% Tuesday.T-Mobile is also near highs, gaining a fraction Tuesday, and is trading back in buy range from a long consolidation after testing support at its 50-day moving average.Meanwhile, Netflix gapped down 13% in heavy volume on its results, hitting a more than 5-month low in intraday trade. The move has Netflix undercutting its 50-day line, which is a key area of support for a stock. Shares are now trading 35% below their December high.

Stellar Q2 earnings results at T-Mobile US (TMUS) and its marketing momentum make it less likely the Deutsche Telekom (DTEGY)-controlled firm will be acquired soon, says one analyst.Craig Moffett, an analyst at MoffettNathanson, shot down speculation that T-Mobile will be acquired by Sprint (S), Comcast (CMCSA), Charter Communications (CHTR), America Movil (AMX) or anyone else.Comcast, which like T-Mobile posted Q2 earnings early Wednesday, as usual fielded questions about its wireless strategy, noted Moffett."At some point, investors will stop asking when and start asking why T-Mobile and parent Deutsche Telekom would want to sell, at least until the full value of the franchise T-Mobile has built has been recognized in its share price," said Moffett in a research report.Federal regulators blocked AT&T's (T) acquisition of T-Mobile in 2011. They've also signaled opposition to any merger between Sprint and T-Mobile.T-Mobile stock gained 1.5% to 45.64 on the stock market today. Earlier shares touched 45.87, hitting a nine-year high for the third day in the past four trading days. T-Mobile stock has a Relative Strength Rating of 81, putting it among the top 19% of all stocks in performance over the past 12 months.IBD'S TAKE: T-Mobile stock has gained 15% in 2016 but shares have met resistance at around 45 for 18 months. Learn more at IBM Stock Checkup. Big telecom mergers are off the table until government auction of airwaves used by TV station is over.With its Uncarrier-branded marketing campaign, T-Mobile has been gaining market share since 2014.T-Mobile on Wednesday said Q2 revenue rose nearly 13% to $9.2 billion as it added 646,000 postpaid phone subscribers -- topping the 173,000 added by Sprint (S) and the 86,000 added by Verizon Communications (VZ). AT&T lost 160,000 postpaid phone subscribers.T-Mobile EPS fell 40% to 25 cents but still topped expectations for 22 cent profit. Higher borrowing costs ate into T-Mobile profit. It has added debt to fund bidding in the ongoing airwave auction, which started in March. It's uncertain when the auction will end.Sprint stock fell 7.4% on Wednesday, giving up some of the prior two days' gains following that telecom's earnings. Verizon rose 0.9% to 55.32.

Comcast's (CMCSA) broadband prowess makes it a top pick of Morgan Stanley, which also raised its price targets on AT&T (T) and Verizon Communications (VZ).AT&T and Verizon stocks have jumped in 2016 amid growing investor demand for high-dividend-paying stocks as global interest rates fall.Morgan Stanley recently lowered its estimate for the 10-year Treasury rate to 1.25% by year-end 2016 and 1.10% by Q2, 2017. On Monday, Morgan Stanley hiked its PT on AT&T to 45 from 35 and on Verizon to 59 from 50, but noted that Comcast has an edge over telecommunication giants."Comcast remains a top pick," Simon Flannery, an analyst at Morgan Stanley, said in a report. "On broadband, Comcast has taken around 45% to 50% of industry net adds since 2014, and we expect share gains to continue given its current and expected future speed advantage over telco competitors."AT&T stock edged down 4 cents to 42.85 on the stock market today, while Verizon inched up 0.2% to 55.93 at the close.. Comcast stock, which recently hit an all-time high, ticked 2 cents higher to 66.86.IBD's TAKE: Shares in real estate investment trusts (REITs) have also done well in the low-rate environment. Check out the IBD 50 for REIT stocks.Meanwhile, Morgan Stanley cut its rating on CenturyLink (CTL) to underweight from hold and on Frontier Communications (FTR) to equal-weight from buy, partly owing to their geographic overlap with cable TV firms Comcast and Charter Communications (CHTR).Flannery says CenturyLink and Frontier may need to increase capital spending to be more competitive.Flannery upped his Windstream (WIN) PT to 9 from 7. He increased Cincinnati Bell's (CBB) PT to 5 from 3.70.

Cable TV and phone companies have taken a regulatory spanking from the Obama administration. Will federal regulators ease up under the next U.S. president?The Federal Communications Commission won a big court victory in June on net neutrality rules governing broadband networks. Led by Chairman Tom Wheeler, the FCC has proposed new rules on consumer privacy and video competition that are opposed by AT&T (T), Comcast (CMCSA), Verizon Communications (VZ) and other telecoms, but which are supported by President Obama.If Hillary Clinton, the presumed Democratic nominee for president, wins in November, more regulations might be on tap for AT&T, Comcast, Verizon and all internet services providers, analysts say. Republican front-runner Donald Trump's views on telecom policy and mergers are a bit of a mystery, though Republicans normally favor a lighter regulatory touch."The current regulatory regime is viewed as openly anti-cable, so at this point investors may believe that any change at all can only be good news," Craig Moffett, an analyst at MoffettNathanson, told IBD.How soon Wheeler leaves the FCC after the new president is elected is open to debate. Traditionally, the FCC chairman resigns shortly after a new administration takes over. Wheeler, though, has kept his options open, and his term doesn't end until 2018."If Hillary Clinton wins the election, there is a possibility that she asks Wheeler to stay on until she can find a suitable replacement," Oppenheimer analyst Tim Horan said in a report. "But we do not expect it would be a long process."We also believe there would be not much change to the status quo if Hillary is president."President Obama has been outspoken on broadband issues in his second term. In November 2014, he pressured the FCC to impose public utility-type regulation on internet services, citing the Communications Act of 1934's Title II rules. Wheeler proposed the new net neutrality rules along those lines.The rules bar ISPs from throttling, blocking or prioritizing web traffic. Wheeler also extended the rules to include wireless networks for the first time.The U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit in June upheld Wheeler's Title-II based rules, but AT&T quickly vowed to appeal the decision to the U.S. Supreme Court. No appeal has yet been filed.The Obama administration has pushed to make broadband services more affordable for lower-income households, approving deals such as Charter Communications' (CHTR) purchase of Time Warner Cable, completed in May.For Comcast and other ISPs, though, probably the greatest potential danger is broadband price regulation. Wheeler has promised not to regulate prices for internet service, but a future FCC could possibly do so under Title II authority.While it may mean nothing, President Bill Clinton's first FCC chairman, Reed Hundt, rolled back cable TV prices in 1994. During the Democratic primaries, Hillary Clinton talked tough on broadband regulation, likely not wanting rival Sen. Bernie Sanders of Vermont to seize this issue.Cable stocks fell in October when Clinton wrote that U.S. "prices for high-speed broadband are far higher" than in some other countries, though she did not mention price regulation."Clinton is widely viewed as more moderate than President Obama, but she has already singled out broadband in policy statements as something like a public utility," said Moffett.The FCC, meanwhile, is moving ahead with a proposal to require that internet service providers get customer consent to collect data for targeted advertising -- a policy that AT&T says would put it at a disadvantage vs. internet companies such as Alphabet's (GOOGL) Google or Facebook (FB), which do collect data on their users that helps target ads.In another move, the FCC aims to open up the TV set-top box market for more competition. The proposal would require pay-TV and tech companies to jointly develop new standards for devices providing access to cable TV programming. Potential set-top suppliers such as Apple (AAPL), Google or Amazon.com (AMZN) likely would provide their own programming guide and perhaps their own advertising to consumers, analysts say.Hillary Clinton's telecom policy would look like "a third Obama term ... with the same implications in terms of corporate winners and losers," Jonathan Chaplin, an analyst at New Street Research, said in a May research report.The presumed Democratic presidential candidate on Wednesday released what she called her initiative on technology and innovation. It had five main parts, with one of them a vow to assure that every U.S. household is hooked up to high-speed broadband, and that free Wi-Fi is available at public "anchor" institutions, such as airports.Trump, as president, would be a wild card, says Paul de Sa, an analyst at Bernstein Research."A Democratic administration would build on the Obama achievements with a continued focus on competition, broadband and spectrum," de Sa told IBD via email. "Under Trump, there's no idea how important media/telecom will be compared to other priorities or policy direction."Amy Yong, an analyst at Macquarie Securities, agrees. "(Trump) would introduce a level of unpredictability that would be harder for investors to handicap than Clinton," she said in a research report.Trump has criticized many media outlets, claiming their news coverage of his campaign has been unfair. Comcast's NBCUniversal and Trump cut ties in late June 2015. NBCU said it would no longer broadcast the "Miss USA" and "Miss Universe" pageants, which are produced by Trump, because of his views on immigrants. Trump did not star in a new season of NBCU's "The Apprentice" in the fall of 2015, though he did appear on the network's "Saturday Night Live," as did Clinton.Comcast's top lobbyist, David Cohen, has been a fundraiser for Obama and Clinton, according to media reports. Federal antitrust regulators in 2015 thwarted Comcast's proposed acquisition of Time Warner Cable.AT&T's top lobbyist, Jim Cicconi, has also come out for Clinton, the Wall Street Journal reported recently reported, though he's a longtime Republican who worked for Presidents Ronald Reagan and George H.W. Bush.Some analysts have speculated that Trump might be open to mergers that create new U.S. champions in telecom or other industries, but Moffett says that's unclear."Trump is a complete wild card on just about every issue, so why should telecom be any different?" Moffett said. "Perhaps he will be pro-business, perhaps not. Would he view mergers favorably or unfavorably? What if one or both of the companies were foreign-owned, or if part of the rationale were to extract synergies that might move jobs offshore? The truth is, nobody has any idea."AT&T shares rose 0.6% on the stock market today, hitting yet another all-time high. Verizon stock climbed 0.7%, also a new high, but still in buying range. Comcast edged up 0.1% while Charter Communications advanced 1.6%.

Cable TV companies will continue to dominate the consumer broadband market -- a trend which AT&T (T) and Verizon Communications (VZ) can buck with wireless services, but which leaves smaller CenturyLink (CTL) and Frontier Communications (FTR) vulnerable, says Macquarie Securities.Amy Yong, a Macquarie analyst, initiated coverage Monday on CenturyLink with a neutral rating. Yong started Frontier, which earlier this year acquired residential landline assets in three states from Verizon, with an underperform rating.Shares of Comcast (CMCSA), the biggest cable TV firm, hit an all-time high of 67.69 early Monday, closing up 0.4% to 67.41 in the stock market today.Both CenturyLink and Frontier will be pressured as Comcast and Charter Communications (CHTR) continue to boost broadband speeds, says Macquarie's Yong."By the end of the decade, we estimate 65% of broadband share will be in the hands of cable, up from 59% currently," Yong said in a research report. "CenturyLink and Frontier are the most susceptible to cable competition, convergence of wireline/wireless, and the potential threat of wireless substitution."IBD's Telecom Services-Integrated group ranks No. 31 out of 197 industry groups. AT&T leads with an IBD Composite Rating of 98 out of a possible 99, while Verizon sports a CR of 94.Shares of AT&T and Verizon have jumped amid growing investor demand for high-dividend-paying stocks as global interest rates sag.CenturyLink stock also has gained this year, up 20%, but Frontier stock is near even. CenturyLink rose 0.4% on Monday, but Frontier stock was down 1%.CenturyLink, like Verizon, is mulling a sale of its data centers amid fierce competition with Amazon Web Services, part of e-commerce giant Amazon.com (AMZN)."(CenturyLink's) dividend support is solid but unlikely to grow, pending strategic review of data centers," added Yong.

Cable TV companies and media stocks sold off on renewed worries that pay TV cord-cutting is accelerating after AT&T (T) preannounced Q3 financial numbers, including the loss of 90,000 video subscribers.X"We believe cord-cutting continues to gain steam as streaming builds momentum," said UBS analyst John Hodulik in a report. He estimated that the pay TV industry will lose about 1 million subscribers in the third quarter compared with 325,000 in the same quarter last year, based on recent management commentary.AT&T plunged 6.1% to close at 35.86 on the stock market today. AT&T also blamed recent hurricanes for video subscriber losses. Comcast (CMCSA), which in early September warned of video subscriber losses, shed 3.3% to 36.19.Comcast had attributed some of its video subscriber weakness to aggressive promotions launched by AT&T's landline "U-verse"-branded TV service. Analysts say AT&T's DirecTV satellite TV service likely suffered the bulk of its subscriber losses in the third quarter.Shares in satellite broadcaster Dish Network (DISH) fell 5.1% to 49.03 on Thursday. While AT&T bought DirecTV for $49 billion in 2016, analysts say Dish has had trouble finding a suitor amid continued subscriber losses.Both AT&T and Dish have launched internet video services. AT&T said it added 300,000 online DirecTV Now subscribers in the third quarter, offsetting some of the traditional pay TV losses. However, both AT&T and Dish garner less profit from internet services than traditional pay TV, analysts say.While AT&T is losing a net 90,000 video subscribers, it's traditional pay TV customer losses in third quarter are higher — 390,000 — partially offset by the addition of 300,000 internet video subscribers.IBD'S TAKE: If you want to understand the state of the market, read IBD's Stock Market Today columns throughout the market day, and the end-of-day The Big Picture (take a free trial) for timely market analysis and highlighted growth stocks breaking out of proper bases.UBS estimates that Dish's Sling service has 1.8 million subscribers and DirecTV Now 760,000. YouTube, the video website of Alphabet's (GOOGL) Google, launched a livestreaming TV service in early 2017.So did Hulu, a joint venture of 21st Century Fox Entertainment (FOXA), Walt Disney (DIS), Comcast and Time Warner (TWX). UBS estimates that YouTube has 180,000 subscribers; Hulu has 175,000.Shares in Charter Communications (CHTR) fell 2.6% to 355.71 on Thursday. Altice USA (ATUS) slipped 2.7% to 25.15.Worries over accelerated cord-cutting also hit media stocks. That's because they garner per-subscriber programming fees from cable-TV and satellite-TV companies. Disney fell 1.6% to 96.93, CBS (CBS) slipped 1% to 56.51, and Discovery Communications (DISCA) shed 3.6% to 19.28.AT&T also disclosed that wireless customers upgraded to new smartphones at a slower rate in the September quarter vs. the year-earlier period, sparking speculation over tepid demand for Apple's (AAPL) iPhone 8.Apple stock edged down 0.4% to 156.RELATED:AT&T Stock Falls, Near Key Level For Time Warner DealCan Google's YouTube TV Hit 2 Million Subscribers In A Year?Dish Bulls And Bears Agree On One Thing: What's Coming In Q3

Walt Disney (DIS) might try to play hardball in talks with Netherlands-based Altice Group, a newcomer to the U.S. cable TV industry, analysts said Monday.XAltice entered the U.S. market after purchasing Cablevision Systems in 2016 and Suddenlink in 2015. Its U.S. operations, Altice USA (ATUS), is the fourth-biggest U.S. cable TV company, behind Comcast (CMCSA), Charter Communications (CHTR) and Atlanta-based Cox Communications."Driven by accelerating subscriber losses we would not be surprised if Disney is being ultra-aggressive in its ongoing negotiations with Altice for renewal of carriage of (broadcaster) ABC, ESPN and the rest of its cable networks," said Jeffrey Wlodarczak, analyst at Pivotal Research, said in a note to clients.Neither Altice or Disney has disclosed ongoing negotiations for renewing a programming deal. Altice's U.S. shares fell 2.1% to close at 26.72 while Disney dipped 0.4% to 98.10.Richard Greenfield, analyst at BTIG Research has a similar view. He notes that Disney's sports network ESPN draws the highest fees from pay-TV companies but its viewership has been falling."Unfortunately for Disney, their legacy practice of strong-arming distributors is no longer going to work," Greenfield said in a blog post. "We believe this is especially true with a distributor that is taking a fresh look at the price/value of all programming as it has just recently entered the U.S. market. ESPN/ESPN2 are no longer worth the $7 to $8 per subscriber that they are paid by distributors."IBD'S TAKE: If you want to understand the state of the market, read IBD's Stock Market Today columns throughout the market day, and the end-of-day The Big Picture (take a free trial) for timely market analysis and highlighted growth stocks breaking out of proper bases.Time Warner Cable and CBS (CBS) in 2013 had a brutal battle over fees. Time Warner Cable now part of Charter, blacked out CBS channels in several markets, impacting nearly 3 million subscribers. In a move that could encourage companies to attempt more mergers, the Federal Communications Commission said in a report Tuesday there is "effective competition" in wireless phone services.Issued as part of the agency's annual report on the mobile wireless market, Tuesday's declaration marks the first time since 2009 that the FCC has concluded that robust wireless competition exists. In January of that year, the last Republican administration left the White House. The five-member FCC now has three Republicans, including Chairman Ajit Pai."Consumer demand and output continue to increase, average prices have been falling, and service providers have enhanced the performance, coverage and capacity of their networks," the FCC said in a news release.SoftBank-controlled Sprint (S) and T-Mobile U.S. (TMUS), majority owned by Germany's Deutsche Telekom (DTEGY), have restarted merger talks, according to reports. Softbank is based in Japan."Is this competition report just the event that Germany and Japan were waiting for to get this party started?" Jennifer Fritzsche, a Wells Fargo analyst, asked in a note to clients.T-Mobile has been gaining subscriber and revenue share vs. AT&T (T) and Verizon Communications (VZ) for three years with its "Uncarrier-branded" marketing campaign. Regulators have preferred a U.S. wireless market with four national players to stoke competition. Regulators blocked AT&T's purchase of T-Mobile in 2011.IBD'S TAKE: Try out premium IBD features for free through Oct. 8. Goldman Sachs says it knows why the telecom industry's merger party has been put on hold.X"Evolving business models, more immediate priorities and regulatory uncertainty have likely limited deal making," Brett Feldman, a Goldman Sachs analyst said in a note to clients.Despite speculation involving T-Mobile US (TMUS), Sprint (S), Charter Communications (CHTR), Comcast (CMCSA), Dish Network (DISH) and Verizon Communications (VZ), no big deals have been announced in 2017.Feldman looked at what might be holding companies back, ahead of Goldman Sachs' annual Communacopia conference. It starts Tuesday in New York.Some deals would create bigger wireless or cable TV companies while others might combine a wireless company with a cable TV firm."As the industry landscape shifts, we believe that major operators are continually re-evaluating their strategic direction and options," added Feldman. 'It is not hard to understand why companies are not rushing into deals that may set their course for the next decade."AT&T (T) Chief Executive Randall Stephenson kicks off the conference Tuesday morning. Europe-based Altice Group, possibly readying an offer for Charter, and Comcast CEO Brian Roberts also are slated for Tuesday.On Wednesday, media firms Viacom (VIA) CEO Robert Bakish and 21st Century Fox's (FOXA) executive chairman Lachlan Murdoch are expected to be on hand. Verizon CEO Lowell McAdam is scheduled to appear Thursday morning.AT&T is awaiting Trump administration approval for its acquisition of media giant Time Warner (TWX), announced in October. A Sprint merger with T-Mobile is still viewed by analysts as the industry's most likely deal.IBD'S TAKE: With thousands of publicly-traded companies to choose from, how can you quickly find the best stocks to buy right now? A good starting point is to regularly review screens that highlight the top-rated equities."Under the Trump administration, we have seen a rapid pace of deregulation by the Federal Communications Commission," said Feldman. "While this implies a potentially more favorable regulatory back drop for pursuing M&A, we have not yet seen the FCC or the Department of Justice weigh in on any major mergers under this administration. As such, the major operators lack context for whether regulators take a different view on market structure than we saw under President Obama."RELATED:Top Questions Apple Will Face At Sept. 12 iPhone EventTelecom Mergers: A 'Game Of Thrones' Without The Dragons

Shares in Charter Communications (CHTR) and its biggest shareholder, John Malone's Liberty Broadband (LBDRA), edged down on Thursday amid more reports that French telecom Altice Group is readying a bid for Charter, the No. 2 U.S. cable TV firm behind Comcast (CMCSA).XShares in Charter have gained 38% in 2017 — spurred on by reports over the months that Verizon Communications (VZ), Sprint (S)-owner SoftBank Group and now Altice are interested in buying it. Some analysts say Comcast looms as another potential buyer.Media baron and cable TV industry pioneer Malone is key to whatever happens, says Jonathan Chaplin, an analyst at New Street Research, in a report. Malone's Liberty Broadband owns a 20% in Charter, holds voting rights and has two board members."Charter will not do a deal that is bad for Malone," said Chaplin. "We assume Malone would never do a deal that is good for him and bad for public shareholders; however, he wouldn't do a deal that is not in his interests, even if some public shareholders may prefer it to the status quo."Amy Yong, an analyst at Macquarie Securities, said in a report published Thursday that "(Liberty) has the power to dictate Charter's free cash flow and (merger) path."Altice founder Patrick Drahi, much like Malone and Softbank founder Masayoshi Son during their business careers, has used debt-fueled deals to build up Altice. Altice owns French wireless firm SFR and much more.Altice USA (ATUS) went public in June. It gobbled up Cablevision Systems and Suddenlink.Altice, however, missed out on a bigger deal. When federal regulators thwarted Comcast's proposed acquisition of Time Warner in early 2015, it was Charter that quickly nailed down a deal with TWC as Altice looked on.Now Altice is back, but Malone may not be ready to cede control. In the media industry, Malone-controlled Discovery Communications (DISCA) and Lions Gate Entertainment (LGFA) also are viewed as consolidators.IBD'S TAKE: Comcast stock has climbed 18% in 2017. Comcast has formed a cup chart pattern and is approaching a buy point of 42.28. Comcast split its stock 2:1 earlier this year. Learn more at IBD Stock Checkup.In January, Malone suggested that Comcast and Charter could attempt a merger during the Trump administration. In May, Comcast and Charter formed a wireless pact."We have no doubt that Comcast has considered an acquisition of Charter, nor do we doubt that Charter would view this deal as very compelling," added Chaplin. "We believe both management teams are very wary of the long-term regulatory risk. We believe the management teams are likely more concerned about their treatment under the next administration than they are about getting a deal approved under this administration."RELATED:Sprint CEO: Merger Announcement Should Be Coming In Near FutureComcast, Charter Forge Wireless Alliance, Fuel Merger SpeculationThink Your Wireless Carrier Is Planning A Merger? Sprint (S) shares flirted with double-digit gains Tuesday after Chief Executive Marcelo Claure teased Wall Street with merger talk, even though there are reports that parent Softbank's talks with cable TV firm Charter Communications (CHTR) have reached a dead end.XAsked for clarification, Claure told analysts on the company's earnings call that parent Softbank is looking at options both inside and outside the wireless industry. Some pundits had forecast a frenzy of telecom deals after a government auction of spectrum ended in April but that has not materialized."We don't discuss a lot of what happens as it relates to (mergers)," Claure said. "We're going to leave that to an announcement that should be coming in the near future."There had been speculation that Softbank founder and CEO Masayoshi Son was in talks to arrange financing for a bid for Charter, which has stated no interest in merging with Sprint. Wall Street still views T-Mobile US (TMUS), controlled by Deutsche Telekom (DTEGY), as the best fit for Sprint, but those negotiations seem stalled."We have a company that now can be sustained on a standalone basis but the potential synergies and value creation of some sort of horizontal or vertical integration will be significantly better than a standalone basis," Claure said. "We have talked to different players and hopefully we'll be able to come to terms in the near future."Shares in Charter popped on Monday on speculation that Japan-based Softbank could aim to force a shotgun marriage with Sprint by making a bid for the No. 2 U.S. cable TV firm. But they retreated in early trading Tuesday, off 1.1% to 387.60.Sprint shares were up 11.15% to 8.87 on the stock market today after the telecom reported a fiscal first-quarter profit.Craig Moffett, analyst at MoffettNathanson, says Softbank's public courting of merger partners could be counterproductive."The obvious risk in so openly courting one potential suitor after another is that Sprint will increasingly be viewed as damaged goods. Like an unsold house that has sat too long on the market, as asset that has been shopped too often without success takes on an air of taint," Moffett said in a note to clients.IBD'S TAKE: Sprint stock is even in 2017 after jumping last year amid on-and-off again merger speculation involving T-Mobile, which is the top-ranked stock in IBD's Telecom-Services Wireless group. Learn more at IBD Stock Checkup.Softbank, which already has a large debt load, owns about 83% of Sprint. Sprint (S) stock slipped Monday as Wall Street analysts questioned why Sprint-owner Softbank would woo billionaire Warren Buffett as an investor and how a possible merger with T-Mobile US (TMUS) figures into the scenario.XSprint was down 1.5% to 8.42 in the stock market today after rising Friday amid media reports that Softbank chairman Masayoshi Son had engaged in talks with Warren Buffett over investing in struggling Sprint. Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway has shied away from telecom investments recently.Softbank's Son also reached out to cable TV industry baron John Malone, said reports. Malone's Liberty Broadband (LBRDK) is the biggest investor in Charter Communications (CHTR).If Buffett and Malone were to invest $10 billion to $20 billion in Sprint as reports suggested, Softbank would give up a range 23% to 37% of the company, said Walter Piecyk, analyst at BTIG Research. Japan-based Softbank owns about 83% of Sprint.The reports raise "more questions than not," said William Power, analyst at Baird in a report."Where's the strategic benefit and why would Sprint be looking for more capital when it has claimed its current liquidity is more than sufficient?" he added.Amir Rozwadowski, analyst at Barclays is in the same camp."We are scratching our heads on several lingering questions," Rozwadowski said in a report. "We recognize that our imaginations may be limited in understanding how a potential transaction could benefit all parties involved. First and foremost, what is the justification for a capital injection?"IBD'S TAKE: Sprint stock is even in 2017 after jumping last year amid on-and-off again merger speculation involving T-Mobile, which is the top ranked stock in IBD's Telecom-Services Wireless group. Learn more at IBD Stock Checkup.Craig Moffett, analyst at Moffett Research, doubts Buffett would be interested unless a T-Mobile merger were feasible. A deal faces regulatory and other hurdles, such as the combined company's debt."It may well be that a T-Mobile deal would only be possible if Sprint's balance sheet were first completely restructured, either through bankruptcy or a massive injection of new equity," Moffett said in a blog. "And while an infusion of outside equity would certainly relieve the pressure on Sprint to quickly strike a deal with T-Mobile, it is hard to imagine that anyone would want to make a big equity investment without a deal."T-Mobile reports second-quarter earnings on Wednesday.RELATED:This T-Mobile Streak May Come To An End During Q2 EarningsCould Buffett Invest In Sprint After Selling Off AT&T, Verizon Stakes?Berkshire's Warren Buffett Sees $12 Billion Windfall From This BankThese 5 Warren Buffett Stocks Are In Buy RangeWarren Buffett Makes $9 Billion Return To Investment That Cost Him Big

Discovery Communications (DISCA) agreed to buy Scripps Networks Interactive (SNI) for $11.9 billion in a bet that uniting ownership of cable channels like Animal Planet and HGTV will help the company adapt to the changing television landscape.Discovery, one of billionaire John Malone's key holdings, will acquire Scripps for about $90 a share and assume long-term debt of $2.7 billion, bringing the total price of the equity value plus liabilities to $14.6 billion, according to a statement Monday. The price represents a 34% premium over Scripps' closing price of $67.02 on July 18, the day before news of the companies' talks became known.Discovery, based in Silver Spring, Maryland, is grappling with shrinking audiences at some U.S. channels — including the Discovery channel and Animal Planet — as consumers drop cable subscriptions and get more entertainment online from Netflix (NFLX) and others. The deal combines two companies that specialize in so-called unscripted programming, focused on real-life adventures, travel, wildlife and home. With Scripps, Discovery gets the home-improvement channel HGTV, where hits like "Property Brothers" and "Fixer Upper" have made it one of the more popular cable networks.The combined company will have almost 20% of the ad-supported pay-TV viewership in the U.S., according to the statement. Buying Scripps could also help Discovery boost its international sales, which currently account for half of its annual revenue. Knoxville, Tennessee-based Scripps owns an interest in Polish TV operator TVN and is expanding HGTV to new countries."This agreement with Discovery presents an unmatched opportunity for Scripps to grow its leading lifestyle brands across the world and on new and emerging channels including short-form, direct-to-consumer and streaming platforms," Scripps Chief Executive Officer Kenneth W. Lowe said in the statement.Discovery's offer had forced Viacom (VIAB) to abandon its own efforts to acquire Scripps, people with direct knowledge of the matter said last week.Scripps rose 1.25% to 88 before the opening bell in the stock market today. Discovery Communications dipped 0.4% to 26.69.After being left out of some new online TV packages in the U.S., Discovery has been looking to create a low-cost web-only TV service with its cable channels and those of others for consumers who don't want to pay for sports, people with knowledge of the matter said in April. Neither Discovery or Scripps broadcasts live sports in the U.S.Though smaller, Scripps has an especially valuable asset in HGTV, which was the fourth-most watched U.S. network in prime time this year, with an average of 1.51 million viewers a night through July 16, according to Nielsen data. Parties to the Scripps Family Agreement control 92% of the voting stock.Deal talk is picking up in the TV industry as network owners grapple with the decline in cable and satellite services amid online competition. Liberty Media's Malone also has discussed a deal to buy all or part of Spanish-language broadcaster Univision Holdings, according to people familiar with the matter.Pay-TV distributors like Charter Communications (CHTR) and AT&T (T) have grown through acquisitions in recent years, giving them added leverage in fee negotiations with channel owners like Viacom, Discovery and Scripps. That's led some network owners to conclude they need to sell as well. Time Warner (TWX), owner of TNT and HBO, agreed last year to be bought by AT&T (T) for $85.4 billion.Cable and satellite-TV providers pay fees to channel owners for the right to carry their channels, and the negotiations have grown more tense now that more pay-TV subscribers are cutting the cord.Network owners are also beginning to offer their own online services to compete with Alphabet (GOOGL)-owned YouTube and Netflix. CBS (CBS) offers its flagship network and Showtime as standalone services online. Walt Disney (DIS), which owns ESPN, is developing an online service to reach sports fans who aren't using traditional cable.RELATED:Is Softbank Eyeing Charter Bid, Shotgun Marriage For Sprint?

While global markets have been in turmoil since the U.K. voted Thursday to leave the European Union, North American investment banks sense buying opportunities among beleaguered tech stocks.Morgan Stanley on Monday released a list of 28 U.S. stocks to buy on Brexit-related weakness. The investment bank said it looked for quality names that "may have been caught up in the sell-off despite limited exposure to the macro effects."The tech stocks selected by Morgan Stanley included Alphabet (GOOGL), Amazon.com (AMZN), Apple (AAPL), Charter Communications (CHTR), Facebook (FB), IBM (IBM), Level 3 Communications (LVLT), Proofpoint (PFPT), T-Mobile U.S. (TMUS) and Workiva (WK)."For each of these names, we believe the post-vote weakness creates an opportunity to add to positions," Morgan Stanley said.Investment bank Jefferies said in a research report Monday that there are U.S. stock-buying opportunities amid "the wreckage" of the Brexit sell-off.Jefferies polled its analysts for "stocks where they believe the recent sell-off may be too punitive — presenting medium- and long-term opportunity."Jefferies chose 27 stocks that its analysts believe offer trading opportunities from the recent sell-off.Tech stocks selected by Jefferies included Mimecast (MIME), Priceline Group (PCLN) and NXP Semiconductors (NXPI). Priceline and other online travel stocks, though, got hammered Friday on the Brexit fallout, since they do a lot of business in the U.K. and Europe. After falling more than 11 % Friday, Priceline stock was down 3.7% to 1,186.05 at the close on the stock market today, touching a four-month low at 1,148.Jefferies offered words of caution with its stock picks."We acknowledge that volatility may persist at high levels for a while, but for those who believe that disruptions like this can create medium- and long-term opportunities, we wanted to offer some stock ideas," the bank said.RBC Capital Markets analyst Mark Mahaney on Sunday offered his post-Brexit stock picks from the internet sector."The Brexit shock has likely created some compelling buy opportunities among some of the highest quality internet stocks, especially Netflix (NFLX), Priceline, Alphabet and Expedia (EXPE)," he said in a report.UBS analyst Eric Sheridan focused on large-cap companies for his Brexit stock picks in the internet and interactive entertainment sectors.In a report Sunday, he listed his current top picks as Alphabet, Priceline, Expedia, eBay (EBAY) and QVC Group (QVCA). He also recommended Facebook and Amazon as key long-term holdings.After falling more than 4% on Friday, the tech-heavy Nasdaq composite index lost more than 2.4% Monday.

Netflix (NFLX) could sway Comcast (CMCSA) and Charter Communications (CHTR) into making a Netflix app available on set-top boxes by cutting a deal similar to what it has with Apple (AAPL), says Morgan Stanley.Apple garners a 30% commission on any digital purchases made from apps listed in its iOS app store. Netflix last year enabled in-app subscriptions for iOS users for the first time.“We think Charter, and perhaps even Comcast, could move to integrate Netflix into their video offerings,” Benjamin Swinburne, a Morgan Stanley analyst, wrote in a research report.He said there’s upside for Netflix if it can add “older demographics,” which he called a “key area where it remains under-penetrated.”While Comcast and Charter have been holdouts, Swinburne pointed out that Dish Network (DISH), Suddenlink, Cablevision Systems (CVC) and Verizon Communications (VZ) offer Netflix or Hulu apps.“We would expect Netflix to give up some economics, similar to other distribution partners like Apple or TiVo (TIVO), but we do not believe it would meaningfully alter the direction of Netflix profits over time,” Swinburne said. “Payments to distribution partners are reported in marketing expenses on Netflix's consolidated financials.”The Morgan Stanley analyst, though, says the cable TV firms might see a reduction in pay-per-view movie revenue if they integrate Netflix content into set-top boxes.Netflix stock, down about 12% in 2016, closed up 1.15% in the stock market today. Morgan Stanley maintained its overweight rating on the stock.Shares of Comcast and Charter lost 0.2% and 1.45%, respectively on Monday. Charter recently acquired Time Warner Cable and Bright House Networks, becoming the No. 2 cable TV firm behind Comcast.
